column3: "title": "Helping Creators Test Content and Earn Rewards | Meta for Creators"
column7: "post_text": "Test Different Reels Content to See What Works BestSelecting the right image and text to accompany your reel helps draw your audience in
column8: but it can be hard to know what will resonate. We\u2019re rolling out a Reels A/B testing tool that allows creators to test different captions and thumbnails on their mobile device to see which one performs best.While creating a Reel on mobile
column9: you can test up to four different captions or thumbnails. Results of the test will appear in your professional dashboard and we\u2019ll automatically display the winning variant on your profile or page unless you change it. We\u2019re also experimenting with incorporating generative AI to help you create different caption and thumbnail options in the future. You can also now easily convert your videos and Lives into Reels by selecting a video or livestream in Your Content on mobile and editing it before posting to Facebook.Track Your Progress and Earn RewardsOver the past year
column10: we\u2019ve rolled out a number of features in professional dashboard to help you learn tips and earn badges for reaching your goals.We\u2019re now rolling out the Achievements hub in professional dashboard where you can see all your achievements across Education
column11: Stars
column12: Reels and Progression in one place. There\u2019s also a new achievement called Reels streaks earned by posting Reels on a weekly basis. Note: users will only see achievements they are eligible for.And while these Achievements on their own may help you grow on Facebook
column13: to make them even more worth your while
column14: we\u2019re testing rewards for reaching different milestones. Creators who are 18+ that finish all Progression levels can become eligible to get increased visibility in Feed or have the Rising Creator label featured on their page or profile \u2013 both of which help you get discovered more easily.And once you\u2019ve completed all the Progression levels
column15: you\u2019re eligible to participate in our newly launched weekly challenges. Every Monday a new challenge sets a series of tasks designed to help you continue your creator journey
column16: such as posting or replying to comments a certain amount of times or reaching a designated number of reels plays or interactions.Manage Your Content In One Place We\u2019ve added a content management tool to professional dashboard where you can see all your posts
column17: reels and videos in one place. From there
column18: you can easily view each individual post and take actions like hiding it from your profile and pages or moving it to the trash. You can also see content performance insights. Previously
column19: creators had to go through each post individually in their feed.Access More InsightsWhether you create content on Facebook or crosspost from Instagram
column20: Insights in professional dashboard provide the information you need to analyze your performance on Facebook and make more content that will resonate with your audience.Now when you visit Insights you\u2019ll see your account highlights for the week (both aggregated and individually)
column21: revealing insights on your posting habits
column22: your audience and your content\u2019s performance.When you dig into content insights you can now view data spanning the past 90 days
column23: a notable increase from the previous 28 day timeframe
column24: providing a more comprehensive understanding of your content's long-term performance.We\u2019ve also rolled out a number of new Reels metrics on professional dashboard
column25: including Reels-specific Reach broken down by followers and non-followers
column26: a distribution score that tells you how your Reel did compared to your other Reels and an audience retention graph showing how long your audience watched a Reel and when they stopped watching it. We\u2019re also updating our Reels plays metrics to include replays
column27: so you\u2019ll have a better sense of how each Reel is performing and which ones resonate most with your audience.Find Answers When You Need HelpAnd finally
column28: we\u2019re launching search and shortcuts in the Creator Support Hub on mobile within professional dashboard. When troubleshooting something or wanting to learn more about a topic
column29: the search function will show you relevant Help Center articles to answer your question \u2013 no more scrolling article-by-article for answers! New shortcuts on popular topics will bring you directly to the right place to easily check on your monetization eligibility
column30: see payout information and learn more about products such as Meta Verified.We\u2019ll continue enhancing professional dashboard to make it even easier to find what you need. "}

column3: "title": "Making money on Facebook: Creators share how they monetize their content | Meta for Creators"
column7: "post_text": "\"Facebook has a much more diverse audience than a lot of other platforms
column8: it's very worldwide
column9: \u201d creator Wasil Daoud shared with Insider
column10: \u201cso your content reach can be a lot greater.\u201d Connecting with this audience has paid off for the food creator
column11: who\u2019s earned over $9
column12: 000 on Facebook alone since January 2023. According to the Insider article
column13: tapping into Facebook has helped increase his income from social media significantly\u2013he\u2019s earned 30 times as much in Facebook revenue by reposting his videos
column14: compared to other short-form video apps.Fellow food and recipe creator
column15: My Nguyen
column16: shares Wasil\u2019s views. \"There's so many ways to make money on Facebook that my manager calls it a cash cow
column17: \" she told Insider.Topping 3 billion monthly active users
column18: Facebook is home to one of the world\u2019s largest communities. According to the Insider article
column19: creators see less competition on Facebook and more opportunity for category ownership. It\u2019s a high reach
column20: high reward equation that\u2019s paying off. \"There's room to be the first in your niche on Facebook and monetize off of that
column21: \" Wasil said.Monetizing content on Facebook can take many forms. Here are 5 things you can do now to start making money on Facebook: 1. Turn on Professional Mode (ProMode) or set up a Facebook PageWhen you get started as a creator on Facebook
column22: you get to decide whether to turn your profile to Professional Mode or create a separate Facebook Page. Both ProMode and Pages unlock professional tools to help you build a following and earn money. Which one is best for you? Here are some thoughts:If you\u2019re building your personal brand using your name and you want to bring your friends and family along the journey with you
column23: use your current profile and turn on Professional Mode. You can post to your friends only or to a public audience. If you\u2019re building a business or making an account for a pet
column24: create a Facebook Page to manage that presence separately from your private personal profile.Follow these steps to turn on professional mode:1. Go to your Facebook profile.2. Below your profile header
column25: click or tap the menu button (\u2026) on the right side.3. Click or tap Turn on professional mode.4. To confirm
column26: click or tap Turn on and complete the flow.Learn more about ProMode and Facebook Pages.2. Understand which monetization products you\u2019re eligible forAs a creator
column27: you may be eligible for different monetization products if you meet Facebook's Partner Monetization Policies. Here\u2019s how to find out if your Page or Professional Mode profile is eligible:To find out if your Page is eligible:1. Go to Meta Business Suite desktop.2. On the left
column28: click the Monetization tab to see an overview of your status and Page eligibility.3. Select the Page you want to check in the top-left dropdown menu.You will see if you have any monetization violations in the Status section. You can also see if you have recent violations in the Policy issues tab on the left. If you click on View Page Eligibility
column29: you will find more detailed information about your Page\u2019s access to monetization tools: At the top
column30: you\u2019ll see a list of monetization tools you are eligible to use. Click Set up to get started using a tool.Click the arrow to the right of Other monetization tools to see a list of tools you aren\u2019t eligible to use at this time.Under each tool
column31: click View criteria to see criteria that must be met in order to use it.To find out if your Professional Mode profile is eligible
column32: you must have professional mode turned on.1. Go to the Professional dashboard on mobile.2. Go to Tools to Try.3. Select Monetization.From here
column33: you will be able to see monetization programs and professional tools available in professional mode.If your Profile is eligible for a monetization tool
column34: when you select a tool (for example: Stars) you will see prompts to set it up.If your profile is not eligible for monetization
column35: Not yet eligible will appear above the list of monetization tools. Note: Click on an individual tool to see criteria that must be met in order to use it.If you do not see monetization programs under Tools to Try
column36: you may reside in a country where monetization is not yet available.3. Learn more about monetization toolsStars: Think of Stars like tips: They\u2019re a virtual good that your community can send you during Live
column37: Reels and on-demand videos
column38: to show you love.Subscriptions: Your most engaged fans can pay a monthly subscription fee to receive access to exclusive Facebook content. Ads on Facebook Reels: These ads integrate seamlessly into your reels
column39: so you get paid while entertaining your fans.In-Stream Ads: With options ranging from pre-roll to mid-roll and image ads
column40: you can tailor the experience yourself or opt for automatic placements\u2013all while keeping your content front and center.Performance bonus program: This invitation-only program gives creators the opportunity to earn money on interactions on their public Facebook posts
column41: excluding reels and Stories.4. Consider collaborating with other brandsGet access
column42: get discovered and get paid: Work with brands to promote their products and services
column43: and unlock earnings. Learn more about Branded Content.5. Check Professional dashboard regularly to track your earningsCheck your earnings
column44: manage payout settings and more in Professional dashboard
column45: currently available for Professional Mode and Pages on the new Pages experience. Learn more about Professional dashboard.Get started earning money on Facebook today."}

column3: "title": "New Ways to Engage your Followers with Broadcast Channels on Facebook and Messenger | Meta for Creators"
column8: Mark Zuckerberg announced we\u2019re bringing broadcast channels to Facebook and Messenger. Broadcast channels are a public one-to-many messaging tool where creators with Pages on Facebook can directly reach and engage more deeply with their followers. Creators can use broadcast channel features like polls to get instant feedback from your community
column9: send behind the scenes photos or videos
column10: and use voice notes for more authentic expression. Broadcast channels are the newest addition in an already robust toolkit of Facebook features that help creators build communities and better engage with their followers. We\u2019re currently testing the ability for Pages to create broadcast channels and expect to roll this experience out in the coming weeks. Anyone on Facebook can join these broadcast channels to stay up-to-date on the latest from their favorite creators and to dive deeper into the topics that matter most to them. Getting Access: Broadcast channels are not currently available in all countries or on all platforms. If you do not see broadcast channels for your Page and your Page has more than 10
column11: 000 followers
column12: you may be able to request early access here.How It Works: If you manage a Page on Facebook in a market where broadcast channels are currently available
column13: you can start a channel directly from your Page or within your inbox on both mobile and web.Once the broadcast channel is created and the first message is sent
column14: followers of that Page will receive a one-time notification to join the channel. Anyone on Facebook can find the channel
column15: but only those who join the channel will receive notifications when an update is posted in the channel. People can leave the channel at any time or mute notifications by tapping the \u201cmute\u201d icon at the top right corner of the channel thread.Only the creator of the channel can send messages
column16: but members of the broadcast channel can react to messages and vote in polls.Click here to learn how to join a broadcast channel on Facebook and MessengerGet inspired by other creators  Below are some broadcast channels on Facebook and Messenger you can join now. NetflixJay ShettyWWEThe DodoHrithik RoshanShilpa Shetty KundraLeague of LegendsInternational Cricket CouncilGoldmines TelefilmsSafety and Privacy Broadcast channels are subject to Facebook\u2019s and Messenger\u2019s Community Standards so people can feel safe being a part of them. People can report both a broadcast channel itself or specific content shared in the channel
column17: which can be removed if it goes against our policies.Broadcast channels are also public and discoverable chat experiences
column18: so they\u2019re treated differently than private messaging on Facebook and Messenger. We have tools and reviewers to help us identify
column19: review or remove content in broadcast channels that may violate our Community Standards \u2014 often before anyone sees it. "}

column3: "title": "From college athletes to Facebook creators: How professional mode helped these two creators transform their careers | Meta for Creators"
column7: "post_text": "We recently announced several product updates to professional mode
column8: including new profile features and layout updates that display content more prominently and make professional mode creators easier to discover and follow compared to regular Facebook profiles. Now anyone can become a creator on Facebook by turning on professional mode in their profile settings. We\u2019ve seen so many content creators find success on our platform already and we\u2019re excited to share their stories with you. Whether you are a professional athlete
column9: a chef
column10: a gamer or simply have a unique perspective on life
column11: Facebook is a platform for you to showcase your talents and grow your audience. In fact
column12: two college athletes
column13: who never imagined becoming creators
column14: turned to professional mode and found success beyond their expectations. Meet Molly McLeod
column15: a cheerleader and cheer coach who grew her following on Facebook to more than 51K followers. Molly\u2019s journey began at 2 years old when her parents enrolled her in gymnastic classes. She quickly fell in love with the sport and spent the next 15 years of her life dedicated to her goal of competing in the Olympics. Unfortunately
column16: that dream was cut short when her injuries became too severe to push through. All of that changed for Molly in high school when she discovered cheerleading. Over the years
column17: Molly\u2019s passion for cheerleading led to many accomplishments such as joining the US National Cheer Team as the youngest member \u2013 even competing overseas. Throughout this time
column18: Molly recorded herself practicing and improving her skills constantly and posting them to Facebook for her friends and family to see. As a visual learner
column19: this was her way of documenting her progress. Today
column20: she creates content that showcases the sport she loves and inspires people to chase their dreams. After turning on professional mode
column21: Molly started to see her profile grow almost overnight. Within a day
column22: her first reel had reached 20k views and within a week she received 25k followers. Molly noticed that after turning on professional mode
column23: her follower count also began to grow on other social media platforms. This ripple effect of increased visibility and engagement helped boost her recognition as a professional creator. My teammate told me that I needed to start posting on Facebook and that the effort I put into my content deserved to generate me some income. He had already had a lot of success with his platform and explained to me that Facebook would bring me the most amount of growth and the opportunity to earn the most income compared to any other platform. Molly McLeod
column24: professional mode creatorSome of her favorite professional mode tools include the ability to monetize her content
column25: which has given her the income needed to continue cheering
column26: coaching and providing more content to her fans. Molly enjoys using the fan engagement tools which allows her to recognize her top fans and thank them for supporting her craft. Turning professional mode on has given Molly the ability to track the success of her content so that she can continue to supply the type of videos her fans are excited about. The first thing she does after opening facebook is to check professional dashboard so that she can stay in the loop on how her profile is performing. I have seen an incredible amount of success since turning on professional mode. It\u2019s crazy to even think about how quickly my following and engagement grew after using this feature. Within a month of turning on professional mode and posting Reels
column27: I was generating averages of more than a million in post reach and it has just continued to grow. Molly McLeod
column28: professional mode creatorMeet Ian Gunther
column29: professional gymnast at Stanford University who saw earnings grow by 30%.Ian started gymnastics at an early age of 5 years old and has been training ever since. That came to an abrupt halt when the COVID-19 pandemic hit and all in-person trainings were shut down. As a temporary outlet
column30: Ian turned to content creation and started creating gymnastic videos online. He saw his audience grow and realized he wanted to use his platform to promote men\u2019s gymnastics
column31: a historically dying sport. Since turning on professional mode
column32: Ian\u2019s Facebook profile has grown to over 100K followers
column33: and has accrued over $12K in revenue. By having access to professional tools and monetization opportunities
column34: Ian was able to increase his earnings by 30%. This opportunity also helped him gain more sponsors and help advance his professional career. By creating a larger and more professional and polished online presence I\u2019ve been able to attract more sponsors and increase ad revenue.Ian Gunther
column35: professional mode creatorLastly

column3: "title": "Evolving and Expanding Ads on Reels | Meta for Creators"
column8: we began testing Ads on Facebook Reels as a way for creators to earn money for creating and sharing engaging public reels. We're accelerating expansion
column9: inviting thousands more creators to join our updated tests
column10: including many of the creators who previously participated in our Reels Play bonus program on Facebook. And in the coming weeks
column11: we\u2019ll begin testing a similar program on Instagram.We\u2019re also evolving the program
column12: testing a new payout model that pays creators based on the performance of their public reels
column13: not the earnings of ads on their reels. This means creators can focus on creating engaging content while we optimize the ad experience for advertisers and people. How to EarnInitially
column14: payouts in the test will be determined by the number of plays. The better their reels perform
column15: the more creators can earn. Over time we may begin to incorporate other signals into payouts. We're learning through our tests that payouts tied to performance are better at balancing the needs of everyone. Many variables outside of creators\u2019 control have traditionally influenced their ad earnings
column16: such as how many ads have already been shown to the person viewing their content or whether there\u2019s a relevant ad to deliver that viewer. With a performance-based model
column17: creators can focus on the content that's resonating with their audiences and helping them grow; advertisers get access to more ad inventory to reach more people; and people get a more consistent viewing experience with more relevant ads. All creators onboarding to the test will automatically be added to the new payout model
column18: and over the coming weeks creators previously testing Ads on Facebook Reels will be transitioned. In addition
column19: we\u2019ll begin to test Ads on Instagram Reels with a similar performance-based payout model among a small group of creators and advertisers in select markets.We also plan to start testing a performance-based payout model for In-Stream ads on Facebook with a small group of creators. While Reels continues to grow quickly on both Facebook and Instagram
column20: creators come to our platforms to share all types of video and we want to support creators making all types of content. To learn more about In-Stream ads and its recently updated eligibility requirements
column21: visit here. How to ParticipateTo be eligible for an invite on Facebook
column22: creators must live in one of 52 countries and meet several minimum requirements. Eligible creators previously part of our Reels Play bonus program on Facebook may receive an invite over the coming weeks if they haven\u2019t already. Once added to the test
column23: in order to earn from Ads on Reels
column24: creators must complete the onboarding process which includes accepting the terms of use and providing payout details. From there
column25: they just need to continue creating engaging Reels to earn. To check if you\u2019re part of this initial program on Facebook
column26: visit Professional Dashboard and go to the Monetization Tools section. If you are invited
column27: you should see \"Ads on Reels\" and you can select \u201cSet up\u201d to begin onboarding.Many Ways to EarnWe\u2019re still early in our work with Ads on Reels
column28: and we\u2019ll continue to monitor these tests closely as we work toward the best solution for creators
column29: advertisers and our apps broadly.Ads on Reels is just one of our many monetization tools that empower creators of all sizes and stages to earn steady streams of income on Facebook and Instagram. Eligible creators can also earn from the support of fans through Subscriptions
column30: Stars and Gifting
column31: from brand partnerships via our creator marketplace and from Facebook through in-stream ads and our Performance Bonus program. To learn more
column32: check eligibility and start earning
column33: visit FB for Creators and Instagram for Creators."}

column3: "title": "2.3M followers on Facebook: how Karim Jovian fostered a powerful community | Meta for Creators"
column7: "post_text": "Facebook: What has it been like creating on Facebook?Karim Jovian: I started making videos in 2009. I\u2019d post them to other platforms and share the links on Facebook
column8: because they would do so well. Then when Facebook allowed sharing native videos I started posting on there as well and saw a lot of traction almost immediately. From there
column9: I started creating more exclusive content.How would you describe your strategy on Facebook?On Facebook
column10: I\u2019m very experimental
column11: I think Facebook rewards experimentation
column12: especially in the types of formats you can post. I started trying square videos which fit mobile phones better
column13: and just seemed to perform better. More recently
column14: I\u2019ve been experimenting with creating 9:16 portrait mode videos [i.e. Reels] which are getting really popular.I also have a predictable schedule that my audience knows: Every Friday I post a new long-form video
column15: with new short-form videos near daily. It seems like connecting with your audience
column16: and engaging with them through comments
column17: is a key part of your strategy. Why is that important to you?It\u2019s very important to take the time to stay connected with the people who comment on my content. I try to respond to as many comments as I can. Especially if someone has a Top Fan badge
column18: it lets me know they are extremely engaged.A really good feature I like on Facebook is that it lets you know if you\u2019re getting more distribution based on your quality content and engagement\u2013 it basically rewards me for engaging in meaningful ways.What tools on Facebook have helped you find success?I use the scheduling feature in Reels a lot
column19: as well as hashtags
column20: and make sure to try any new tools that get released on an ongoing basis. I also use Creator Studio Meta Business Suite to check my insights to see which videos are doing well
column21: and which ones need some more love.If a video is not performing as expected
column22: I will often take it down
column23: make some tweaks
column24: and re-upload it at a better time. On Facebook
column25: there is also a great long tail where older videos can resurface and start garnering views all of the sudden.Not too long ago I released a video in widescreen [16:9]
column26: it did okay but I decided to switch it up and make it mobile-friendly. So I re-edited it as a square [1080x1080] and uploaded it in the morning. Over the weekend
column27: it became the most viral video I have. Where do Reels fit into your overall strategy?I\u2019ve been leaning into more short-form and Reels. A lot is shifting toward that shorter and more mobile friendly content
column28: and it shows immediately\u2013the engagement and growth I saw when I started focusing on Reels was amazing. Some of the monetization that is available for Reels
column29: like Ads on Facebook Reels or Stars
column30: has also made it a really sustainable format.What tips would you give to aspiring creators?Just try it
column31: don\u2019t wait. Especially when it comes to Reels. Facebook is more sustainable than other platforms because of the revenue options. Now it\u2019s one of my main platforms
column32: just because I gave it a shot. If you start
column33: that\u2019s half the battle.Also: post quality content
column34: make sure you don\u2019t have any logos [watermarks] from other platforms
column35: post directly to Facebook and have fun with it\u2013be true to yourself and let expectations go.What is your vision for the future?I\u2019ve been a content creator for so many years and I\u2019d love to keep creating content. I feel like it\u2019s so important for me as an artist. I look forward to continuing growing
column36: especially on Facebook
column37: I\u2019m looking for it to become even more sustainable. My goal right now is to push Ads on Reels and keep leaning into Reels because they're really fun
column38: they are straight to the point and have a nice cycle to them that can introduce my audience to all my other content as well.In the eventual future
column39: I\u2019m really hoping to have my own show.Just try it
column40: don\u2019t wait. Especially when it comes to Reels. Facebook is more sustainable than other platforms because of the revenue options.Karim Jovian"}

column3: "title": "Supporting creators across Instagram and Facebook | Meta for Creators"
column7: "post_text": "EXPRESS YOURSELFSelf-expression and creativity are at the center of any creator\u2019s journey; and we want to make it as easy as possible for creators to tell their story through formats that fit their unique needs and creative styles. Across Instagram and Facebook
column8: creators can use a mix of feed posts
column9: stories
column10: reels
column11: lives
column12: messaging and more \u2013 and we're constantly building new tools and improving existing features to meet creators' needs.We\u2019ve heard over and over again that creators want to be able to foster the important connections they have with their communities. On Instagram
column13: features like Notes and Broadcast Channels are new easy ways to foster community
column14: by engaging with fans directly. On Facebook
column15: creators have options to meaningfully connect with fans and other creators
column16: whether it\u2019s through comments and conversations
column17: groups
column18: or features like weekly engagement lists and templates that make it easy to recognize your top fans. GROW YOUR AUDIENCECreators are drivers of culture and inspiration \u2013 and we want to help them get discovered by the audiences who love their content. Reels in particular allow creators to connect with new audiences through short-form video
column19: and are a key driver of growth for many creators on Instagram and Facebook. We're also using AI to put your posts in front of the people who may be most interested in them \u2013 within Feed
column20: Explore and Reels.Creators have additional tools to help drive their growth: hashtags help people discover content from creators they don't already follow; cross-posting lets you share your Instagram Reel to Facebook and vice versa to easily reach more people; and collabs expand your reach by co-authoring feed posts and reels with someone else.We also know it\u2019s important for creators to simply manage their presence. The creator account on Instagram has tools to help manage messages
column21: understand growth with insights
column22: use flexible controls
column23: and schedule posts. The Account Status tool lets you know if your account\u2019s content is eligible to be recommended - and how to fix any issues. We\u2019ve also expanded Professional Mode for Profiles on Facebook
column24: which enables creators to easily convert their personal profile to a public account and gain access to community and monetization tools to optimize their growth and content strategy. EARN MONEYWe want to make it possible for any creator to make a living on Instagram and Facebook. We strongly believe in helping creators earn on our platforms and have built a suite of tools to allow them to do that \u2014helping them get support from their fans
column25: partner with brands and earn money directly from Instagram and Facebook: From fans: Creators can develop deeper connections with their most engaged followers through subscriptions on Instagram and Facebook. Dedicated fans can connect with and show appreciation for their favorite creators by sending Stars based virtual gifts on Facebook and Instagram.From brands: Brands and creators can partner for branded content deals - using Instagram\u2019s creator marketplace to connect & develop partnerships
column26: and the paid partnership label to disclose them across Instagram and Facebook.From Meta: With in-stream ads on Facebook
column27: creators can earn money when ads are shown during their on-demand or live videos
column28: and we\u2019ve been testing overlay ads on Facebook Reels as a way for creators to earn money for their Facebook Reels. On Instagram
column29: we are evolving our Reels Play bonus and exploring ways to run the program in a more targeted form. STAY SAFESafety and well-being \u2013 and cultivating a positive community \u2013 are foundational to any creator finding success on our apps. We offer a number of features and controls to empower creators across Facebook and Instagram to manage and prevent unwanted interactions
column30: like with our Hidden Words feature on Instagram that allows them to block certain words or phrases from comments or message requests
column31: or our Moderation Assist feature on Facebook. We also let people hide comments in bulk
column32: pin selected comments
column33: or restrict certain people from messaging them entirely. We also provide support to troubleshoot issues and educate creators on how to be successful on our platforms through our expansion of Creator Support
column34: Live Chat
column35: Education Hub and Safety School. And importantly
column36: to avoid access issues
column37: you should set up two-factor authentication. But if it\u2019s too late for that
column38: and you believe you have been hacked
column39: we also created Instagram.com/hacked - to report and resolve account access issues.You can read more about our work to support creators here. "}

column21: you had close to 2M followers on Instagram. Tell us about that journey.Alzahabi: My journey as a food creator really took off during the pandemic. With more people staying at home and exploring their culinary interests
column22: social media became a hub for sharing and discovering new recipes and foodie adventures. I saw this as the perfect chance to take my passion for cooking to the next level and share it with the world.I started posting daily videos
column23: sharing my love for food and cooking tips
column24: and before I knew it
column25: my following was skyrocketing! I then shifted my focus to building a brand and I am more determined than ever to bring joy and positivity through food to those who follow me.How would you describe your strategy?My approach is to make cooking and food accessible
column26: visually appealing and quick to make. Accessible: I always strive to create content that appeals to a wide audience and I try to make sure everyone can easily recreate these dishes at home.Vibrant
column27: unique visual ID: I'm all about making my recipes visually appealing. That's why I love to pan the camera down from the food to my face and add in fun
column28: personable cuts with instructions. My signature black T-shirt and white background help bring out the vibrant and delicious look of my dishes.Authentically myself: I aim to bring personality and energy to my cooking content and encourage my audience to join in. I\u2019m excited this year to showcase more of my personality
column29: experiment with different content series and give everyone a glimpse into the things that inspire me.Consistency: My posting schedule is consistent
column30: with a focus on daily content creation. I aim to never miss a day without posting something new and exciting for my followers.Feedback loop: I focus on bringing my followers the freshest content possible and encourage them to cook along. By doing so
column31: they naturally become more invested and engage with my content
column32: asking questions about cooking techniques and sharing their own creations.Dream team: I've been the mastermind behind all of my videos
column33: from setting up my studio to lighting
column34: camera work and editing. But the future is looking even brighter because I've recently put together a top-notch team to help with production and bring folks even better content in 2023!Evolution: My approach is dynamic and I adapt to my creative flow. While I've primarily focused on short-form content in the past
column35: I'm excited to take things to the next level by diving into longer-form content and giving my followers a deeper look into who I am and what I stand for.About a third of your followers come from reels
column36: as these short-form
column37: entertaining videos often reach a large unconnected audience (meaning people that don\u2019t follow you). Do you think about turning viewers into followers?I believe in giving people the best possible experience and providing value in every video. The key to keeping my followers engaged and invested is by delivering consistently high-quality content. My strategy is to showcase my culinary skills and add my own unique personality and flair to each video. Whether it's a new recipe or cooking tip
column38: I'm dedicated to providing the best possible experience and making sure people leave feeling inspired and informed.How do you approach audience engagement?Earlier in my career
column39: I would spend around six hours a day actively engaging with my audience\u2013not just on my own posts
column40: but also in other communities. My followers appreciate my cultural awareness and sense of humor
column41: and if it's not evident in my videos
column42: you can often find me cracking jokes and having a great time under other people's posts.Collaborating with other creators is also a great way to reach new audiences
column43: as I always stay true to myself and bring the fun with me wherever I go.Your success on Instagram has extended beyond posting content that resonates with many on the platform. What has this success afforded you?My success on Instagram has allowed me to turn my passion into a full-time career
column44: enabling me to live my dream as a creator and bring my vision to life.The exposure I've received through appearing on a popular network TV show and brand deals has helped me establish myself as a brand
column45: attract new opportunities and invest back in my business. With the support of my followers and team
column46: I have been able to create higher quality content and scale my impact
column47: driving me towards my ultimate goal of bringing about positive change.What\u2019s your vision for the future?With a warm and inviting smile

column49: I hope to inspire others and bring about positive change in the world. It's time to take my impact to the next level and use my love for food to create a ripple effect of kindness and generosity.I'm also thrilled to announce a partnership with a youth programming and leadership center in Flint
column50: Michigan
column51: where I'll be teaching food nutrition and cooking classes to underrepresented youth in Flint
column52: Chicago and NYC. I believe in giving people the best possible experience and providing value in every video. The key to keeping my followers engaged and invested is by delivering consistently high-quality content.Ahmad Alzahabi

Don\u2019t worry about how many followers you have\u2013care about how engaging you are. When you show true connection and take into consideration fan feedback

column3: "title": "Inside Xiaoguo Comedy\u2019s Reels-first launch strategy"
"title": "How Marion Grasby sold out her cookware line | Meta for Creators"
column7: "post_text": "Results60K+ recipe booksSold out cookware lineAll results are self-reported and not identically repeatable. Generally expected individual results will differ.With a sold-out cookware line and over 60K recipe books sales
column8: Marion Grasby has nailed the recipe for sales success on social media. Video content and community engagement are the linchpin of her sales strategy for the Marion\u2019s Kitchen range of products. Marion\u2019s videos are posted regularly across her six Facebook and Instagram Pages
column9: capturing the eyes and taste buds of hungry scrollers who are then invited to purchase her tasty wares.Marion\u2019s Kitchen product rangeMarion\u2019s Kitchen growing product range includes the Marion\u2019s Kitchen Food range
column10: Cookbooks and MAKO - a performance cookware line - all of which she sells through her Facebook Pages.Marion recently launched her performance cookware brand MAKO
column11: with the Black Steel 14 Wok as the flagship product. \u201cWe sold 6 months\u2019 worth of stock in 10 days! We have another shipment on the way
column12: as well as a range of great new MAKO products coming in 2023.\u201dHer cookbooks - also sold through social media - have also been a big success. Always Delicious sold 40K+ in the first month and the follow up
column13: Just As Delicious has sold 20K+ to date.Content and community drives sales\u201cThe relationship with our community has been built over the long term.\u201d Says Marion
column14: \u201cContent and community is the heart of our business.\u201dMarion and her team work hard to maintain a sense of community and engagement for those following Marion\u2019s Facebook pages. \u201cWe always aim to maximize the audience experience and customer service by engaging with Followers as comments and questions come in.\u201dThis community of foodies loves to have fun - they especially enjoy witnessing the relationship between Marion and her mum
column15: Mama Noi. The team found evidence of this through a combination of post analytics and noting sentiment in the comments of content featuring Marion and Mama Noi.\u201cHaving well established a personal connection with the community
column16: we find the fun content of myself
column17: and Mama Noi together is always extremely effective.\u201d She says
column18: \u201cOur relationship resonates with our community.\u201d5 product launch tips from Marion:1Create a range of content formats. Product launches call for a range of content formats. We create an engaging mix of long and short form video
column19: photography
column20: live events and other information on our products.2Measure and review. Measure the success of organic content and optimize the content that's performing most effectively.3Have fun. Content doesn't always have to be serious. We try to capture the authentic fun we have while recording
column21: especially with Mama Noi. It helps our followers feel closer to us.4Mix up your marketing plan. We often use a mix of paid and organic content
column22: depending on the campaign.5Check your tech. Make sure you're well prepared for live events
column23: especially product launches. A stable internet feed is key when doing a live launch party!"}

column3: "title": "Testing Meta Verified to Help Creators Establish Their Presence | Meta for Creators"
column7: "post_text": "To help up-and-coming creators grow their presence and build community faster
column8: today Mark Zuckerberg announced that we\u2019ll begin testing a new offering called Meta Verified
column9: a subscription bundle on Instagram and Facebook that includes a verified badge that authenticates your account with government ID
column10: proactive account protection
column11: access to account support
column12: and increased visibility and reach. We\u2019re starting with a gradual test in Australia and New Zealand later this week to learn what\u2019s most valuable
column13: and we hope to bring Meta Verified to the rest of the world soon. Some of the top requests we get from creators are for broader access to verification and account support
column14: in addition to more features to increase visibility and reach. Since last year
column15: we\u2019ve been thinking about how to unlock access to these features through a paid offering. With Meta Verified
column16: creators get: A verified badge
column17: confirming you\u2019re the real you and that your account has been authenticated with a government ID.1More protection from impersonation with proactive account monitoring for impersonators who might target people with growing online audiences. Help when you need it with access to a real person for common account issues. Increased visibility and reach with prominence in some areas of the platform\u2013 like search
column18: comments and recommendations.2Exclusive features to express yourself in unique ways.3Meta Verified is available for direct purchase on Instagram or Facebook in Australia and New Zealand starting later this week. People can purchase a monthly subscription for (USD) $11.99 on the web and (USD) $14.99 on iOS and Android.4There will be no changes to accounts on Instagram and Facebook that are already verified based on prior requirements. Long term
column19: we want to build a subscription offering that\u2019s valuable to everyone
column20: including creators
column21: businesses and our community at large. As part of this vision
column22: we are evolving the meaning of verified accounts on our apps so we can expand access to verification and more people can trust the accounts they interact with are authentic.Building Safety from the BeginningIt\u2019s important to feel confident that your identity and accounts are safe and that the people you\u2019re interacting with are who they say they are. That\u2019s why we\u2019re building a series of checks into Meta Verified before
column23: during
column24: and after someone applies.To be eligible
column25: accounts must meet minimum activity requirements
column26: such as prior posting history
column27: and be at least 18 years old.5Applicants are then required to submit a government ID that matches the profile name and photo of the Facebook or Instagram account they\u2019re applying for.Subscriptions will include proactive monitoring for account impersonation.We're also committed to continuous monitoring and review of reported violations
column28: as well as taking swift action against those who try to evade our systems.To learn more about Meta Verified and see Mark Zuckerberg\u2019s Meta Channel on Instagram
column29: click here on your mobile device.1Where available
column30: some subscribers may be required to submit a selfie video as part of the authentication process.2 This feature is currently only available for subscribers in Australia and New Zealand. Increased visibility may vary depending on a subscriber\u2019s existing audience size and the topic of their posts. Subscribers with a smaller following may see a more noticeable impact to their reach since their audiences are smaller. All Meta Verified subscribers and their content must meet our Terms of Use and Community Guidelines. All content will be treated according to our existing guidelines for recommendations on Instagram or Facebook and our Content Guidelines. 3 We\u2019ll offer exclusive stickers on Facebook and Instagram Stories and Facebook Reels
column31: and where available 100 free stars a month on Facebook so you can show your support for other creators. 4 AUD 19.99 on web
column32: AUD 24.99 on iOS and Android. NZD 23.99 on web
column33: NZD 29.99 on iOS and Android.5Businesses are not eligible to apply for Meta Verified at this time. See all Meta Verified eligibility requirements here."}

column3: "title": "How Sujin Kim found success cross-posting reels from Instagram to Facebook | Meta for Creators"
column7: "post_text": "RESULTS:Followers grew over 600% in just one month
column8: May - June
column9: 20223+ minute video revenue grew from almost nothing to a 5-digit monthly revenue in USD in a month. May - June
column10: 2022All results are self-reported and not identically repeatable. Generally expected individual results will differ. STRATEGY:South Korea-native Sujin Kim
column11: known as @Chinguamiga
column12: began producing videos during the pandemic and on-site classes were canceled. Her videos became a vehicle to teach the Korean language and culture to a growing local audience. Soon her content evolved to portray not only her hometown heritage
column13: but also the differences (and similarities) between Korea and Mexico. Hence her username\u2013Chinguamiga\u2013the first half of which means \u201cfriend\u201d in Korean
column14: and the second half means \u201cfriend\u201d in Spanish.When Chingu discovered Reels
column15: they quickly became a key pillar of her content strategy. Then Meta introduced cross-posting for reels
column16: which enables Instagram Reels on Facebook
column17: and Sujin\u2019s popularity increased even more. \u201cI managed to reach a larger audience because they are different audiences
column18: \u201d she said.Since she started posting her Instagram Reels on Facebook
column19: her followers grew 600% on the platform in a month
column20: and her revenue on videos of more than three minutes grew from almost nothing to a 5-digit monthly revenue in USD from May to June. She relies on posting long videos daily
column21: along with 30-second reels. That content mix is highly strategic: Reels reach a wide audience
column22: which she is then able to monetize through her longer-form video content.She is also highly analytical
column23: studying new trends and combing through comments to deliver quality videos that resonate. Constantly in \u201ccreator mode
column24: \u201d Sujin jots down situations from her day to day as they come up
column25: which lend authenticity and relatability to her videos about being a foreigner living in Mexico.Chingu shared the following tips with aspiring creators:1From day one
column26: look for what makes you different from other creators and use it as a source of inspiration.2Make content you yourself enjoy.3Stay consistent. This earns you the trust of your audience.4Know your audience and what trends are successful.5Adapt to the type of content and formats that your followers consume the most.6Always give it a go. Don't be afraid of trying new formulas and ideas.Capitalizing on her success
column27: Sujin has travel plans
column28: and video plans of both the short- and long-variety. Stay tuned at @Chinguamiga to follow along on her adventures."}

column4: humorous and vibrant: How Jesus Nalgas grew his audience 3x in 3 months | Meta for Creators"
column8: "post_text": "Results3x Instagram follower growth

Results are not identically repeatable and generally expected individual results will differ.StrategyConsistency: \u201cI\u2019m always trying to grow my presence by sticking to a consistent upload schedule with Instagram Reels during the day
column12: Stories as I go and Instagram Live in the evening
column13: \u201d said Nalgas. \u201cI try to post three days a week around the same time for my Reels
column14: and all of my skits are original and optimized for Instagram.\u201dRelatability: \u201cI find humor in relatable everyday situations that most people have likely experienced
column15: to shine a light on the struggles or small moments in daily life where comedy lives. When I\u2019m coming up with concepts
column16: I try to make sure my videos begin with a character. From there I\u2019ll identify a green screen background and a wardrobe/prop combination to bring that character\u2019s scene to life.\u201dHook: \u201cIn filming
column17: I make sure I\u2019ve got an immediate hook that brings people into the scene before they scroll to watch something else in their feed. Viewers can feel immediately immersed in the setting of my skit when it\u2019s universally identifiable
column18: like a classroom or an office.\u201dEngagement: \u201cWhen I share my daily life on Stories or go Live with my followers
column19: I\u2019m able to engage directly with my community and that has been a really key factor in my growth and engagement. My followers feel like my friends and I love them for that! They often request scenarios or characters in the comments or during a Live
column20: and I try to take those into consideration when I\u2019m coming up with ideas.\u201d Core memory: \u201cWhen I\u2019m putting my videos together
column21: the dialogue needs to match the scenes to unlock the core memory I\u2019m trying to share with my audience
column22: because more than likely it will be something they\u2019ve all experienced in their own life.\u201d Simplicity: \u201cAll I use is my phone
column23: tripod and sometimes a green screen
column24: and I think that makes me all the more relatable to my followers. I don\u2019t go for super professional editing
column25: the simpler the better.\u201d Confidence: \u201cI think the secret to my growth has been in my confidence as a creator. I\u2019ve taken a natural progression in my content to do less lifestyle content and more character-based comedy and acting
column26: which is where my passion has always been. Once I built a solid foundation and earned the trust of my followers
column27: I was able to experiment and show them other sides of me. Once I knew they liked my humor
column28: I was able to double down and super-serve them the content that they were responding well to.\u201dPositivity: \u201cI like to think that this confidence has helped me tune out negativity to really only focus on what brings positivity
column29: joy and laughter to keep the conversations happening in my community moving in the right direction as we continue to add seats in the tent.\u201dRipple effect: \u201cI\u2019m always looking to be a positive reflection for the Latinx community. If I can shout people out from my hometown or small businesses that I want to support
column30: to see them get love from the rest of my community online has been a huge blessing.\u201dThe secret to my growth has been in my confidence as a creator. Character-based comedy and acting have always been my passion. Once I built a solid foundation and earned the trust of my followers
column31: I was able to experiment
column32: double down and super-serve them the content that they were responding well to.Jesus Nalgas"}

column3: "title": "Reels inspiration and in-stream ads: Laura Mej\u00eda's tips for creativity and unlocking revenue | Meta for Creators"
column7: "post_text": "Colombian creator Laura Mej\u00eda is proud to be gen z
column8: with digital creation and consumption a part of her day-to-day for as long as she can remember. Currently in college for Social Communications
column9: Laura posted her first video to Instagram in 2015 and has seen her audience grow exponentially since. A fan of fashion
column10: beauty and lifestyle
column11: her videos encompass nail and makeup tutorials and pop culture and have generated a legion of loyal followers: She built a community of more than 656K followers on Instagram and 250K on Facebook and defends the importance of always being in contact with the public. \"[It's fundamental] to have a community that enjoys what you do

column13: \" she rejoices.Results110M views

Generally expected individual results will differ. Strategy\"I started creating reels on Instagram when the format first launched on the platform. It seemed like a great opportunity to create short-form content
column15: and after seeing the exposure it was getting

column17: and more and more people were expressing interest in what I was doing
column18: \" she explains.Laura started posting content on Facebook because she wanted to explore the reach that posting to both Meta platforms enables. \"I thought it could be a great way to reach more people and it did

column20: as there are more and more tools to benefit from.\"\"Being consistent is important in order to build your audience. No one is really going to connect with you if you don't upload content on a frequent basis
column21: especially nowadays with so many different

column25: but expanding in order to try things will allow you to provide more diverse content to the audience you already have
column26: and to reach new people.\"For as much success as she\u2019s already had
column27: Laura is enthusiastic about her future as a creator. \"I want to focus on continuing to create content more consistently and getting to know my audience well to understand which videos work better on Instagram and Facebook. I keep experimenting and trying new things to identify what type of content I should invest more time in.\u201d My life has changed because now it's all about the content I make. I'm always looking for ideas

column29: most importantly
column30: I have something that really makes me very happy.Laura Mej\u00eda"}

column3: "title": "Holiday sales and beyond: How creator Christian Hull generates hype for his merch | Meta for Creators"

column3: "title": "Expanding opportunities for creators to earn money on Facebook | Meta for Creators"
column7: "post_text": "Durante queste festivit\u00e0 vogliamo celebrare i creator e contribuire a diffondere l'atmosfera festiva con il nostro nuovo programma
column8: Stars Gifting Season.Regali virtuali stagionali: da oggi fino all'anno nuovo i fan possono acquistare regali virtuali in edizione limitata per sostenere i loro creator preferiti e diffondere lo spirito delle festivit\u00e0.Bonus del party di stelle: dal 7/12 al 21/12
column9: i creator che usano Stars possono ricevere stelle bonus se raggiungono obiettivi prestabiliti. Per maggiori dettagli
column10: dai un'occhiata alla dashboard per professionisti.Promozione sulle stelle: le stelle saranno in offerta dal 14/12 al 4/1. I fan potranno ottenere fra il 5% e il 20% di stelle in pi\u00f9
column11: in base al pacchetto acquistato. \u00c8 possibile acquistare stelle a un prezzo scontato nei video e nel negozio di Stars. La promozione sar\u00e0 disponibile per video live
column12: on demand e reel.Nuove possibilit\u00e0 su Stars e test di nuove funzioni e formatiStiamo semplificando la possibilit\u00e0 di scoprire Stars su Facebook abilitando automaticamente la funzione sui contenuti pubblici dei creator
column13: inclusi quelli pubblicati su Facebook Reels. In questo modo le persone possono venire a conoscenza di Stars e usare le stelle in altri luoghi su Facebook. Stiamo testando questa possibilit\u00e0 per un numero ristretto di creator. Mentre estendiamo Stars all'app Facebook
column14: stiamo introducendo nuove funzioni e formati per contribuire a migliorare l'esperienza di Stars.Pi\u00f9 strumenti per interagire con chi invia le stelle: vogliamo semplificare la possibilit\u00e0 per i creator di interagire con i fan che li sostengono. Stiamo aggiungendo un filtro in Gestione commenti per visualizzare tutti i commenti inviati insieme alle stelle. I creator potranno cos\u00ec rispondere in una volta sola a diversi commenti con stelle. Renderemo disponibili queste funzioni nelle prossime settimane. I creator potranno usarle dalla dashboard per professionisti applicando il filtro \"Inviati insieme alle stelle\" in Gestione commenti.Nuovi regali virtuali: stiamo aumentando i regali virtuali su Facebook Reels e stiamo sperimentando regali personalizzati in base ai contenuti. un nuovo modo per i fan di mostrare che apprezzano i contenuti dei loro creator preferiti. Per iniziare
column15: testeremo regali a tema su diversi argomenti di reel
column16: fra cui animali
column17: auto
column18: moda e danza.Stars on Reels Freebies: stiamo testando il nuovo programma Stars on Reels Freebies
column19: che offre ad alcuni fan stelle gratuite da inviare a creator idonei di reel su Facebook. Creando pi\u00f9 reel
column20: i content creator aumentano le proprie possibilit\u00e0 di ricevere stelle. Stiamo testando questo programma per un numero ristretto di creator in tutto il mondo.I commenti non finiscono mai e Gestione commenti \u00e8 un ottimo strumento che ci consente di garantire un'esperienza ottimale al pubblico
column21: evitando di dimenticare fan e follower nella grande mole di commenti ricevuti.Il team creativo di Lil Jacob WalkerAbbassamento della soglia dei pagamentiStiamo riducendo la soglia per i pagamenti per i creator con sede negli Stati Uniti da 100 a 25 USD. In questo modo
column22: i creator che sono agli inizi potranno essere pagati prima. La nuova soglia per i pagamenti sar\u00e0 valida per Facebook Stars e per gli abbonamenti di Facebook; inoltre nelle prossime settimane sar\u00e0 disponibile per altri prodotti di monetizzazione di Facebook.Continuiamo a offrire ai creator strumenti di monetizzazione pensati per le loro esigenzeInserzioni su Facebook Reels: continuiamo a testare le inserzioni su Facebook Reels con creator selezionati in tutto il mondo. Il test riguarda due formati: inserzioni overlay e post-loop. Le inserzioni overlay sono posizionate nella parte superiore dei reel sotto forma di banner o come adesivo all'inizio del reel. Le inserzioni post-loop sono inserzioni video riprodotte al termine di un reel. Una volta terminata l'inserzione
column23: il reel continua e ricomincia.Abbonamenti: stiamo per introdurre nuovi
column24: semplici modi per consentire ai creator che usano gli abbonamenti di Facebook di promuoversi. Su Facebook Watch abbiamo aggiunto il pulsante \"Abbonati\"
column25: che consente ai follower di abbonarsi mentre guardano i contenuti video dei creator che amano di pi\u00f9.Maggiore supporto per i creatorAbbiamo introdotto nuovi aggiornamenti sulla nostra piattaforma in-app di supporto ai creator
column26: disponibile per Pagine e profili in modalit\u00e0 professionale idonei negli Stati Uniti
column27: per rispondere a domande frequenti con una selezione ampliata di articoli di assistenza e contenuti formativi sulle date dei pagamenti. Stiamo anche estendendo l'accesso all'assistenza degli agenti in tempo reale ai creator idonei di Pagine e profili in modalit\u00e0 professionale
column28: residenti negli Stati Uniti e con almeno 10 000 follower. In questo modo i creator saranno in contatto con un servizio di assistenza in tempo reale in grado di aiutarli a risolvere eventuali problemi di monetizzazione."}

column3: "title": "\u2018What do you do for a living?\u2019: How curiosity propelled Daniel Mac into full time content creation | Meta for Creators"
column7: "post_text": "Results1.8M followers on Facebook & 2M followers on Instagram3 Reels a day posted on either Instagram or Facebook*All results are self-reported and not identically repeatable. Generally expected individual results will differ.Two years ago
column8: Daniel Mac graduated from college in Tucson
column9: AZ
column10: and moved to Dallas to work his first post-college job at a brokerage firm. Daniel was interested in how people built their wealth and managed their money
column11: and it sparked a video idea. Outfitted with a disarming smile and a gracious
column12: curious enthusiasm
column13: he started approaching people in luxury cars and asking them his now famous question: \u201cWhat do you do for a living?\u201d The videos took off
column14: with some reaching millions of likes.Daniel's StrategyEngage immediately and remember: dead space is deadly. You usually have one or two seconds tops to engage a viewer
column15: so get to the fun
column16: engaging part quickly. Be relentless in editing out dead spaces. Make the video fast
column17: punchy and energetically alive every second. Caption everything and caption creatively. Captions create engagement. They put a second layer of content on the first layer of video. Have the captions move
column18: sprinkle them in different locations. Let them lead the viewer to the next frame. Have them create anticipation. Never auto-caption
column19: always do it yourself. Pro-tip: Ask questions. It encourages more comments and audience participation.Act like a pro in professional dealings. No matter your beat or your tone
column20: when it comes to the business side
column21: act like a professional. Get your own custom email address. Respond to your sponsors quickly and professionally. Keep a calendar and stay organized.Develop a formula. Each one of Daniel\u2019s videos follows a familiar pattern: he narrates the scene
column22: letting his audience feel as if they\u2019re right there with him; he always kicks things off with the same question; he\u2019s humble
column23: and grateful
column24: to be speaking to new people. The importance of sticking to a formula is plentiful: Consistency builds habit
column25: which in turn creates anticipation. His audience knows what to expect from him and returns time and time again. New viewers who happen upon his videos understand out the gate what they\u2019re in for. A formula also unlocks one of the most crucial keys to help growth: Scale. When it comes to working with businesses
column26: don\u2019t lowball. When Daniel started working with brands
column27: he wasn\u2019t sure how to go about his rate. The views
column28: reach and awareness he delivered for those brands were far and beyond what he charged. That\u2019s when he learned to command what he\u2019s worth
column29: and has since worked with some of the biggest
column30: most recognizable brands in the world. Assume ownership of the process. Daniel signed with an agency in January of 2022. They now find deals for him and price them but Daniel remains in control of most aspects of production
column31: from filming the videos on his trusty phone to editing
column32: captioning and posting them on various platforms.Take a leap. In the beginning of his journey as a creator
column33: Daniel worked nonstop. He\u2019d work Monday to Friday at the brokerage
column34: fly out to film on weekends
column35: then fly back (exhausted) on Sunday to start the workweek again. The pace became unsustainable
column36: and Daniel quit his day job to dedicate himself fully to content creation. For him
column37: it paid off. He has since traveled the world
column38: met with celebrities and world dignitaries and he even spent a week in India as the only American at Meta\u2019s Creator Day.Looking AheadDaniel is constantly thinking about his next move. He\u2019s been organizing events and meetups to engage the community around his passions. He\u2019s also working on a longer-form video/podcast format
column39: where he\u2019ll explore in depth what successful people \u201cdo for a living.\u201d He imagines a show format that is infinitely fractionable
column40: where choice edits could be as short as a few seconds to longer-form segments that audiences can consume by preference.His advice to aspiring creators: Find your niche or passion and carve a new life. Captions create engagement. They put a second layer of content on the first layer of video. Have the captions move
column41: sprinkle them in different locations. Let them lead the viewer to the next frame. Have them create anticipation.Daniel Mac "}

column3: "title": "Live Creator Camp: create
column4: grow and earn with Live video | Meta for Creators"
column8: "post_text": "Have you ever thought about going live but you weren\u2019t quite sure where to start? Then Live Creator Camp is the solution for you. Live Creator Camp is a video series consisting of 20 \u2018minisodes\u2019 (mini episodes) available now on Meta for Creators. This video series aims to teach creators like you how to get started
column9: grow and monetize on Facebook Live. Tune in to listen to expert advice from the team at Meta as well as unfiltered stories from your favorite creators
column10: including CandyLover89
column11: Dr. Kojo
column12: Tony Directs
column13: Braannxo and more.Check out the Live Creator Camp trailer below.See moreUse Live to build your community:The good thing about going Live is that you can be completely yourself and the right people will love you for that. And don't be afraid to make mistakes! At the end of the day
column14: the important thing is to be real and engage with your community.CandyLover89I love Facebook Live so much. It\u2019s allowed me as a creator to connect with people across the world in such an incredible way! I\u2019ve literally met my best friend through Facebook Live! She lives in Australia
column15: she sent me this necklace I'm wearing now. It's a great space for creators to start building their community.BraannxoUse Facebook Live to engage your community:I love Facebook Live because it lets me engage directly with my audience in a way that feels authentic.Dr. KojoI love Facebook Live because I get to connect in real time with my supporters
column16: while getting to know who they really are. To me
column17: that\u2019s the best way to spend time with my community.Tony DirectsUse Facebook Live to earn a sustainable income through in-stream ads
column18: Stars and more:I am obsessed with Facebook Stars and I love to use them on Live as well as Stars on Reels. Facebook Stars make up nearly 50% of my income from Facebook which allows me to continue to create content and do the job I love.BraannxoI love Subscriptions because it\u2019s allowed me to build a tight knit community! I love in-stream ads because you can set up automatic placements in just a few clicks
column19: start earning and never think about it again.One Funny MotherAnd there\u2019s so much more!With episodes on tactics to promote your live videos
column20: how to approach your Video On Demand (VOD) strategy and how to maintain your well-being while going Live
column21: there\u2019s something in Live Creator Camp for everyone who\u2019s ever been curious about going Live.Watching this series in one sitting
column22: or over time
column23: will leave you feeling empowered and energized to create
column24: grow your community
column25: engage in meaningful ways and monetize your content.Get ready
column26: get set
column27: go live!Watch now"}

column3: "title": "Fan Engagement 101: Best practices to connect and engage with your audience | Meta for Creators"
column7: "post_text": "Best practices for engaging meaningfully with fans:1Understand your fans and their interests2Cultivate a safe space to engage with your audience3Recognize and reward your dedicated fansI have not found a platform that focuses on community more than Facebook. The features that Facebook gives creators really allows us to create a special corner of the Internet that can be centered on just about anything. My community on Facebook is more than just a group of followers\u2013they are individuals from around the world who inspire me on a daily basis. They also help and inspire each other. There simply is no other platform that would allow me to have the community that I do.Tastes SEOUL GoodUnderstanding your fans and their interestsUnderstanding who makes up your community has multiple benefits
column8: from helping you tailor your content to their interests to highlighting who engages with you the most. We know your time is precious
column9: so we\u2019re here to help you answer questions like: Who are my top fans? Which fan engaged most with my content last week? Where are most of my fans from?Professional Dashboard is your one-stop-shop for all insights and performance. Professional Dashboard allows you to view audience and profile insights in aggregate (e.g.
column10: age group
column11: gender
column12: locations of your audience)
column13: as well as the performance of your content (e.g.
column14: engagement
column15: reactions
column16: comments
column17: shares). We recommend you visit your dashboard regularly to keep track of how your content is performing over time.Fans that engage with your content consistently may be rewarded with a special honorary badge
column18: called top fan. With top fans
column19: it\u2019s easy to identify and interact with your most consistently engaged fans while incentivizing them to engage more with you. When these fans comment on your posts
column20: you\u2019ll see the badge next to their name. You can also see a list of all your top fans by clicking on a top fan badge and selecting \u201cSee all top fans\u201d.(Available on professional mode for profiles and new Pages experience)We also recently launched a weekly engagement list that shows your most engaged followers each week along with the number of points they\u2019ve earned that week from interacting with your content (e.g. reacting
column21: commenting
column22: sharing). This list refreshes every Sunday and you can find it in the \u201cAbout\u201d section of your Page.(Available on new Pages experience)The weekly engagement list allows me to recognize those who are most active on 'Tastes Seoul Good'. A little recognition goes a long way
column23: and being able to simply say 'thank you' to my 'penguins' allows them to feel like they're a part of our journey.Tastes SEOUL GoodCultivate a safe space to engage with your audienceThere are many ways to interact with your fans
column24: including the comments section
column25: through DMs
column26: during live streams
column27: in Groups and more!The comments section is a great place to start building community and we\u2019re making it easier for you to join in on conversations around your content. Look for the top fan badge as you scroll through your comments. If you\u2019re short on time
column28: you can prioritize responding to these comments from your most loyal fans. We\u2019re also constantly working on improving notifications to surface the most relevant conversations with which you\u2019ll want to engage.We want to empower you to create a safe space on the platform so that people keep coming back. There\u2019s a suite of comment moderation tools and controls available through Professional Dashboard to help you effectively manage these conversations
column29: including the following key feature:Moderation Assist: Reduce time moderating comments by proactively setting criteria in advance with Moderation Assist. Automatically hide incoming comments on your posts
column30: such as comments with links
column31: profiles with no profile photos
column32: comments with keywords from a curated list and more.Choose Who Can Comment: Limit who can comment on your posts.Comment Ranking: We\u2019ve also improved which comments on your posts appear first to help you find and engage with the most relevant conversations. These improvements include elevating comments and replies from creators to the top of the discussion thread on a post
column33: and decreasing the visibility of spammy or repetitive comments.Find out more information about these and other tools on our new Safety Hub. No matter how you choose to interact with your fans
column34: we\u2019re committed to making sure that you feel safe doing so.Recognize and reward your dedicated fansYour fans are here for you
column35: and it\u2019s important to make sure that they feel appreciated and seen. As with most things
column36: you know your community best. Consider giving a quick shout out every now and then to fans who are consistently showing their support: top fans
column37: Stars senders and subscribers. If you recently achieved an important milestone
column38: think about celebrating with your fans through a fun contest or giveaway.If you need some additional inspiration
column39: Facebook offers several built-in tools to make it easy to show appreciation for your fans\u2019 support. For top fans and Stars senders
column40: we recently launched fan appreciation templates. You\u2019ll receive a notification in the Facebook app and from there
column41: you can access these templates that auto-mention these fans in a post or Story to easily show appreciation for their support. These templates are also available for your weekly engagement list and can be used to recognize your most engaged followers over a given week.(Available on new Pages experience) Make your top fans\u2019 experience even more rewarding by giving them exclusive access to content. This feature
column42: which is already available to subscribers
column43: can be turned on for top fans by going into the post settings in composer. (Available on new Pages experience)Staying connected with my fans is the most important thing for me as a content creator
column44: and a priority in my everyday life. While I'm unable to respond to every comment
column45: message
column46: or email
column47: I always take time out of my day to connect with my followers.Tastes SEOUL Good"}

column3: "title": "These reels helped LGBTQIA+ allies show support during Pride Month | Meta for Creators"
column7: "post_text": "I risultati5 milioni di riproduzioni130\u00a0000 interazioniReel efficaci stimolano la conversazione ed esprimono un punto di vista. La popolarit\u00e0 dei reel #WalkWithPride2022 ha consentito ai creator di partecipare alle conversazioni sul Pride che interessavano loro
