column7: "post_text": "Results57M+ Reels plays30% of plays from cross app posting(June 22 - 11 Sep 2022)Reels-first content strategyReels are the backbone of Karmalogy\u2019s content strategy
column8: \u201cReels is a place for me to showcase my creativity. It\u2019s also become my creative safe zone.\u201d He said
column9: \u201cReels deliver stable engagement
column10: unlike other platforms where one video is a viral success and the next gets lower engagement.\u201d While Agung works a reels-first strategy
column11: he\u2019s also consistently posting other content formats. Each format plays a different role in his strategy. \u201cReels are where I entertain fans and perform in character - I have developed ten different characters.\u201d said Agung. \u201cStories play a different role. I use Stories to connect directly with my fans
column12: as Agung\u201d he said. \u201cI ask my fans for their opinions via Question and Poll Stickers and also respond to their DMs in Stories.\u201d Karmalogy posts every day
column13: averaging at least one Reel and multiple Stories a day. Relatable Reels helped create a communityBuilding an authentic community has been key to Karmalogy\u2019s growth momentum and ongoing success. His strategy to use Stories as a connection channel with his audience has been very successful. \u201cI used Instagram analytics to understand my followers. I saw my viewers are mostly female
column14: aged 24-42
column15: \u201d He said. \u201cSo I set out to create relatable Reels I thought they would connect with - I crafted a series of characters that parody young mums.\u201dThe approach worked
column16: with 70% of Karmalogy\u2019s followers gained from Reels between 22 June and 11 September 2022. Agung\u2019s hilarious characters Fashio-Nista (Nista is an Indonesian term for disgrace) and Mamah Mayang (meaning Mom of Mayang) delivered big plays. This relatable content struck a note with his audience
column17: and soon Agung began to receive DMs from mums
column18: sharing their feedback and personal stories. \u201cEveryday
column19: I receive about 200 DMs. And I read them all!\u201d Agung said
column20: \u201cfans share their stories with me
column21: and sometimes that becomes my inspiration for a new reel. I choose the most relatable stories.\u201d\u201cMany people are amazed how a man like me can impersonate mums and nail them.\u201d He said
column22: \u201cI was raised by a single mum. That inspired me
column23: I watched my mum interact with other mums.A common thread that connectsKarmalogy works smart by creating community-led content. He knows what makes people laugh because he often crowdsources ideas. This is done by posting Stories with interactive Stickers that ask fans for feedback on his characters
column24: video concepts or what they think of hot topics.While Agung never covers politics
column25: he does explore social challenges faced by young mums
column26: like the rising cost of living. Making his audience laugh in the face of challenges is important to him. \u201cBad experiences can become positive.\u201d He said
column27: \u201cmy audience stays on my account because I turn their tough issues into positive content. Satire can deliver positivity!\u201d\u201cMany of my followers are from Muslim communities
column28: I don\u2019t want to offend them. So I play my female figure using a towel and menswear below
column29: I don\u2019t dress completely as a woman - this is a clear differentiator to the audience - I\u2019m making parody content.\u201d he said.Karmalogy\u2019s range of ten characters has been a huge success. These include:Tools that drive distributionAgung also uses two tactics to drive distribution of his reels. 1Trending audio. We asked
column30: what comes first - the audio or the idea? He said
column31: \u201cI like to participate in trends - so trending audio comes first. But I always add my own twist.\u201d2Hashtags. Each of Agung\u2019s reels are posted with multiple hashtags. \u201cI use my own name
column32: I use #receh (translates to cheap comedy in Bahasa Indonesian) and the Meta team suggested I use #TawadiReels (Laugh on Reels in Bahasa Indonesian).\u201d Reels is a place for me to showcase my creativity. It\u2019s also become my creative safe zone.\u2013 Karmalogy"}

column3: "title": "Impulso Local's new edition offers training and funding for Argentine media"
"title": "How Facebook Reels connected creator Bia Napolitano with a new audience and supercharged her career | Meta for Creators"
column8: born in S\u00e3o Paulo
column9: who started creating online just for fun. Being a lawyer
column10: she used Instagram
column11: especially Stories
column12: mostly just to interact with her friends. Having a natural and charming sense of humor
column13: Bia saw her videos start to gain traction beyond just her friends. This is the moment she decided to try being a creator for real.It took me a long time to realize that it could become my profession. It became such a pleasure for me
column14: producing and receiving feedback
column15: seeing numbers grow... It was a career transition. Today
column16: I'm a comedy creator on the internet who can moonlight as a lawyer
column17: if needed.\u2013 Bia NapolitanoBia\u2019s comedy videos deal with subjects that are close to her daily life
column18: like relationships
column19: behavior
column20: self-esteem
column21: motherhood and more \u2013 and have garnered her over 2 million followers on Instagram. On Facebook
column22: since she posted her first reel in May of 2022
column23: Bia has seen her audience jump from 113
column24: 000 to over 518
column25: 000 followers \u2013 a 358% growth in just three months! \"I give the credit for my growth on Facebook to Reels. With the first reel I posted
column26: I already saw great distribution. If the content is good
column27: people will identify with it
column28: watch it and share it. At the time
column29: I had 100-200k followers and I had reels with up to 3 million views.\" Her reels currently reach an average of 1 million people per video! All results are self-reported and not identically repeatable. Generally expected individual results will differ. Bia\u2019s top tips for finding success across Facebook & Instagram:1Focus on authentic content.  Before starting to create Reels with trends
column30: you need to create a persona online. And the more natural you are
column31: the better. So
column32: the content has to be authentic to how you live. The first thing is to be you and that's it.2Posting frequency. Here goes an important tip: people who are not seen
column33: are not remembered. Being present and posting frequently on the platform is essential. 3Relate to your community.  It's important to talk about issues that are related to your universe. I'll give an example of a video that performed really well: I deal with social pressure to have children because I've been married for a long time
column34: I'm over 30 years old
column35: etc. So talking about this pressure engages other women who interact because they identify with it and this is within my universe. 4Shareable content. With this kind of content
column36: you don't necessarily need to delve into topics you want to talk about; it's like memes. An example: the video in which I show the difference between when I wake up at 6:30 in the morning to go to work and when I wake up at 6:30 in the morning to go on a trip. Everyone can relate to that! And the more creative
column37: the better. 5Collaborations. Collaborating with people working with a similar niche is nice because their followers get to know your content as well. The results are really good! Bia is a big fan of the collaborations
column38: especially on Reels. \"I enjoy creating shared reels that go to both profiles. This resource is brilliant because it has much more impact. Instead of just tagging the person
column39: you post together with the other one. Your audience will see the other person's content and vice versa. It's wonderful!\" Finally
column40: she comments on the need to remain persistent and persevere toward the goals you want to achieve. \"It's a daily challenge to keep an audience engaged when they are always expecting something new from you. Creation needs to be constant. You can't get too excited about being praised and you can't be sad about being criticized. Follow what you think is right. Along the way
column41: I met a lot of people who gave up
column42: but who had so much potential to be successful. The biggest challenge is to be able to stay strong and keep going!\u201d "}

column3: "title": "A creator\u2019s guide to growth: Avoiding violations and staying safe | Meta for Creators"
column7: "post_text": "Our GuidelinesWe have two main sets of standards at Facebook:1Community Standards outline what is and isn\u2019t allowed on our platform. Content that violates our Community Standards may be removed from the platform and can result in disciplinary action against your account.2Content Distribution Guidelines give insight into what content receives reduced distribution because it is problematic or low quality. These guidelines were established on three core principles: Responding to people\u2019s direct feedback: These guidelines come directly from our users and represent content that people tell us they do not want to see. Content that falls under this principle include Ad Farms
column8: Clickbait
column9: and Engagement Bait.Incentivising creators to invest in high-quality and accurate content: These guidelines exist to make sure the content on the platform is high quality. Content that falls under this principle includes Unoriginal news
column10: Misinformation
column11: and content from pages that artificially inflate their distribution.Fostering a safer community: These guidelines protect the safety of our users. Content that falls under this principle includes content from repeat offenders
column12: content that links to sexual or shocking content
column13: and content that is borderline to our community standardsAccounts that repeatedly post content violating our Content Distribution guidelines will likely see reduced distribution for their content.As you continue your journey as a creator
column14: you may want to begin earning money for your content. When this time comes
column15: additional standards will apply. To successfully monetize
column16: your account must comply with our Partner Monetization Policies. Additionally
column17: your content must comply with our Content Monetization Policies to be eligible to earn money.How we enforce our guidelinesIf you post content that goes against the Facebook Community Standards
column18: we\u2019ll remove it
column19: notify you and may apply a strike to your Facebook account. Whether we apply a strike depends on the severity of the content
column20: context in which it was shared and when it was posted. You can see the current status of your account in our Page Quality tool
column21: which will help you understand any Community Standards violations you may have incurred on your account. Where creators often run into challengesThere are three specific categories of standards that we often see creators struggle with. Enforcements of these categories often come from following online \u201cGrowth Hacking\u201d advice as opposed to our best practices.1Engagement Bait: Authenticity is key on Facebook. Engagement bait goes against this principle
column22: and leads us to demote individual posts that use it. Engagement bait urges others to like
column23: share
column24: comment or interact with a post. Examples include asking people to react to a post (\u201cLike this post if you\u2019ve found TRUE LOVE!!!\u201d)
column25: asking users to share posts with friends (\u201cShare with 10 friends to win a new car\u201d) or asking people to vote using reactions (\u201cVote on your 2022 goals below!\u201d). More information about engagement bait can be found here.2Limited Originality of Content: To reward creators that do the hard work of crafting and promoting authentic
column26: valuable content
column27: we prioritize content that appears original. Original content reflects the unique voice and value of the creator who creates it. Limited editorialization (posting others\u2019 content with minor enhancements)
column28: aggregation (curating others\u2019 content without meaningful enhancements to the content) and duplicative content (posting content that already exists) are the three most common reasons we see creators violating our Originality rules. To protect your original content and ensure only you are collecting ad earnings for said content
column29: upload your content library into Rights Manager in Creator Studio right away.3Watchbait: Watchbait is content that intentionally withholds information
column30: sensationalizes content or misleads viewers into watching or engaging with a video. Watchbait tactics usually come in three forms: withholding
column31: sensationalism or misleading. Withholding tactics include omitting key information (\u201cHe paid attention at first but then this happened...\u201d) to create an arbitrary information gap. Sensationalism is using unnecessary exaggeration (\u201cSHOCKING weather phenomenon could upend all of your summer plans\u201d) to entice views. Misleading content creates misleading expectations about the payoff of the content; often misleading tactics include using thumbnails
column32: titles or text overlay that implies something happens in the video that doesn\u2019t. We have heard clearly from users that they feel betrayed or let down when withholding
column33: sensationalism and misleading tactics are used to bait them into watching videos and using such tactics will likely result in video or Page-level demotions.Where to go for help and supportWe are expanding Facebook\u2019s Creator Support. Previously
column34: support was offered via an external website for a small cohort of English language
column35: US based
column36: creators who did not have an assigned relationship manager from Meta. Now
column37: we are moving to an in-app Creator Support experience. The new hub will give creators access to support and education materials to help resolve common Issues like monetization eligibility
column38: bullying
column39: verification requests
column40: etc. Eligible Creators will also receive access to speak directly with live chat agents. The early version of the new Hub will be used to test different features and audiences. Ultimately
column41: the Hub will roll out to all Creators on the Facebook platform. To access the Creator Support Hub:1 Click your profile picture (menu button).2Click Help & Support.3Click Creator Support. We will notify Creators via email as the new Creator Support portal becomes available to more CreatorsWe\u2019ve gone through how distribution works
column42: what our best practices look like and how we keep the community safe. You now have the tools and knowledge necessary to help grow your audience
column43: but this is not the end. Continue experimenting. Try new formats and content to see what works for you! Continue iterating and listening to what your audience is telling you. Continue creating and bringing your authentic self to the platform every time you do. We can\u2019t wait to see what you create!To recap:Our Community Standards outline what is and isn\u2019t allowed on Facebook.Our Content Distribution Guidelines govern what content gets reduced distribution Creators often struggle with three policies in particular: Watchbait
column44: Limited Originality of Content and Engagement Bait."}

"title": "Branded Content on Facebook Reels: a new way to partner with brands | Meta for Creators"
column7: "post_text": "Cosa sono i contenuti brandizzati su Facebook Reels?Nell'ambito del nostro continuo impegno per aiutare i creator a trasformare la loro passione in un lavoro
column8: stiamo lanciando i contenuti brandizzati su Facebook Reels in tutto il mondo. Poich\u00e9 Reels \u00e8 lo strumento in pi\u00f9 rapida crescita di Facebook
column9: i reel rappresentano per i creator un formato eccellente da usare nelle campagne con contenuti brandizzati. I creator possono ora usare lo strumento di tag per i contenuti brandizzati (con etichetta per le partnership pubblicizzate) su Facebook Reels nei loro post organici e i brand taggati possono convertire tali reel in inserzioni con contenuto brandizzato (con etichetta per le sponsorizzazioni). In tutti i contenuti dei creator che citano un brand o un prodotto o ne sono influenzati in funzione di uno scambio di valore (ad esempio
column10: un pagamento o omaggi gratuiti) deve essere taggata la relativa azienda. Il partner commerciale taggato ricever\u00e0 una notifica e alcune metriche riguardanti il tuo post.Chi ha l'idoneit\u00e0?I creator che soddisfano le Normative sulla monetizzazione per i partner potranno usare lo strumento per i contenuti brandizzati. Per mantenere l'idoneit\u00e0 all'uso di questo strumento
column11: i creator devono inoltre rispettare le Normative sui contenuti brandizzati
column12: che vietano di promuovere determinati tipi di contenuti usando lo strumento per i contenuti brandizzati e indicano le best practice che consentono di promuovere alcune categorie di contenuti soggette a limitazioni usando tale strumento. I post con contenuti brandizzati non conformi a queste normative sono soggetti a rimozione da parte di Meta. Scopri di pi\u00f9 su queste normative e su come richiedere un controllo nel caso in cui i tuoi contenuti siano rimossi a causa di una violazione.Come faccio a creare un reel di Facebook con contenuti brandizzati?Per iniziare
column13: scarica la nostra guida alla configurazione dei contenuti brandizzati su Facebook Reels
column14: che fornisce istruzioni dettagliate
column15: e scopri di pi\u00f9 non solo su funzioni del prodotto come il pulsante \"restrizioni del pubblico\"
column16: che consente di limitare le persone autorizzate a vedere i tuoi contenuti in base all'et\u00e0 o alla posizione
column17: ma anche su come autorizzare i partner commerciali a creare inserzioni con contenuto brandizzato su Facebook Reels e molto altro. I creator e i brand che usano Facebook come strumento di collaborazione continuano a essere una fonte di ispirazione per noi. Ci impegniamo a supportare queste collaborazioni per consentire ai brand di continuare a sfruttare il potere delle voci dei creator per raccontare la loro storia e aiutare al tempo stesso i creator a crescere e vivere di questo."}

column3: "title": "A creator's guide to growth: best practices for growing your Facebook presence | Meta for Creators"
column8: start creating with ReelsIf you\u2019re just starting on Facebook
column9: start with Reels. Reels are immersive
column10: entertaining videos with editing functionality
column11: audio
column12: effects
column13: and creative tools that you create and watch on Facebook and Instagram. Reels not only appear in Feed
column14: but on your timeline
column15: watch tab and throughout the Facebook app. Making reels according to our best practices is truly one of the best ways to get noticed by new people and get your name out there.Post frequently and consistentlyPosting high-quality content frequently can increase opportunities for audiences
column16: existing and new
column17: to see content that they love.Posting consistently gives viewers another reason to return often to see what new content you\u2019ve posted.Fresh
column18: original content
column19: along with engaging with your audience
column20: can help build a strong community.Use Post ComposerWe are constantly working to give creators the best tools possible to create. A new tool in the toolbox is our Post Composer tool
column21: designed to streamline the process of creating a post and simplify content creation on Facebook.Use Post Composer to schedule your posts in advance
column22: view recommended times for optimal post scheduling and cross-post your content to specific Groups where you know your audience will be.Follow our content type best practicesIt\u2019s important to remember that one size doesn\u2019t fit all. That being said
column23: we do have some general best practices that may be useful as you create on Facebook.Reels: Reels are short form videos (up to 60 seconds) that can unlock huge growth potential for creators
column24: through including new more opportunities for creativity
column25: discoverability
column26: audience development and monetization. Reels are shared as Public by default
column27: which enables your content to be discovered by new audiences
column28: thus allowing you to grow your reach. Our best practices for Reels include avoiding recycled content
column29: bringing your unique twist to the trends of the day and experimenting with our tools and new formats to make content that your audience will find engaging and shareworthy.Long Form Videos (LFV) (Not Including Reels): Longer form video (also sometimes called Video on Demand or VOD) allows you to create content at a variety of lengths. In order to get your videos seen
column30: make sure you make videos that are original
column31: engage audiences from start to finish
column32: encourage loyalty amongst your viewers (i.e.
column33: they come back to watch time and time again) and spark meaningful interaction with your fans. Use our checklist and our 10 tactical best practices to optimize your video posts.Live: Going Live can be a great opportunity to deepen your connection with your fans. Helpful tips for live streaming can help you make the most of those live interaction moments.Non-Video Posts: The best non-video posts are those that grab the attention of the user right away. Use striking visuals and engaging language to make your posts actionable and encourage interaction with your fans.Stories: The best Stories take advantage of the unique
column34: ephemeral nature of a story. Grab viewer attention by maximizing the impact of the first frame of the story. Vary the scenery and locations of where you are shooting to entice your viewer. Remember that you can use multiple Stories to tell a full narrative and bring the viewer along with you.Engage with your audienceThe most successful creators are those who don\u2019t just build great content
column35: but build great communities as well. Engaging regularly and authentically with the audience you have built is critical in growing your following and distribution on Facebook.Engagement is not a one-way street; prioritize a two-way dialogue with your community. Ask open-ended questions
column36: respond to mentions and DMs and build your reputation as an approachable creator. Make sure to use some of the tools that we have to help make this easier. The Top Fans tool can help you identify and engage with your most ardent fans and cheerleaders. The redesigned Live experience makes it easier than ever to host a live Q&A session. Show your community some love and they\u2019ll return it in spades.Measure results and adjustWe have built a variety of tools to help you understand your impact on Facebook. Use these tools to analyze and adjust your creation to help meet your own personal goals.Through in-app notifications
column37: you will receive insights on your weekly follower growth and tips on how to grow your audience. Make sure to check these notifications frequently. Reviewing your Professional Dashboard can enable you to understand how your content is resonating with users. The most successful creators are those who never stop learning
column38: measuring and adjusting to meet their audience where they are.To recap:1When in doubt
column39: start with Reels. Reels are a great way to reach new fans. 2Create content authentic to yourself that engages your fans. Original
column40: engaging and meaningful content can help you to reach new fans and grow your audience. 3Measure your results frequently to see what is working and where you can improve. Read More:A creator\u2019s guide to growth: how to get your content seen on Facebook"}

column3: "title": "European news publishers build big business through Meta Accelerators"

"title": "Four ways journalists can enhance digital safety ahead of elections | Meta Journalism Project"
"title": "It's election season: best practices to help you safely engage with your community | Meta for Creators"
column7: "post_text": "A vote counted is a voice heard. Leading up to elections
column8: we want to ensure people are connected with reliable voting information and that everyone feels safe engaging in these conversations.With each major election around the world
column9: Meta\u2019s comprehensive strategy remains focused on protecting elections online. We invest a huge amount on safety and security\u2014not just during election periods but at all times\u2014to make sure people feel prepared to participate in the civic process. We\u2019ve compiled various resources that creators can use to make their voice heard and engage with their communities safely during elections season.Raise voting awareness with Profile Frames on Facebook and Instagram StickersEmpower your audience with authoritative election sources with these features on Facebook and Instagram. You can add a Profile Frame to your profile picture on Facebook. A post will be published to Feed
column10: directing people to the Voting Information Center for reliable voting information. On Instagram you can add Stickers
column11: available in English and Spanish
column12: to your Stories. When people tap these Stickers
column13: they\u2019ll be directed to official election information based on the state they select.Five ways you can enhance your digital safety ahead of electionsTalking about elections with your community can have a great impact
column14: but it can sometimes lead to unwanted interactions. By familiarizing yourself with different moderation and safety tools that are available on Facebook and Instagram
column15: you can help ensure your content and accounts remain secure. 1. Turn on two-factor authenticationHelp safeguard against phishing attempts to compromise your information. By enabling this security feature
column16: logging into your Facebook or Instagram account from an unknown device requires both the account password and an SMS code sent to your phone or email. Enable on FacebookEnable on Instagram2. Run privacy and security checkups on Facebook Facebook\u2019s tools allow you to manage your account security and privacy with a few simple steps. Facebook\u2019s Security Checkup evaluates your password strength
column17: two-factor authentication
column18: and login attempts
column19: while Privacy Checkup guides you through adjusting your account settings to control who can see what information you share.Start Security CheckupStart Privacy Checkup3. Moderate your conversations Elections can create intense community dialogues about sensitive topics. When engaging in these conversations
column20: you can utilize various tools across Facebook and Instagram to help facilitate healthy conversations and minimize unwanted interactions. On Facebook:Limit unwanted messaging or commentsFilter out harmful keywords and posts with profanityBlock intrusive accountsReport abusive content or impersonation attemptsOn Instagram:Limit DMs and comments from those who don\u2019t follow youFilter out messages and comments containing specific wordsApprove tags before they appear on your ProfileRestrict or block accountsReport abusive or spam contentAny combination of these tools can be enabled to protect the integrity of your posts and account. You can also proactively moderate new comments on your posts using criteria you set in advance. Plus
column21: you can always pin positive comments or sort to view comments by \u201cmost relevant\u201d to ensure you\u2019re engaging with high quality comments from your community.4. Get a refresher on digital safety Brush up on digital safety best practices by stopping by the Safety & Well-being hub. There
column22: you\u2019ll find helpful resources and tips
column23: like the Safety School for Creators webinar
column24: where we show you how to verify and secure your account
column25: inform you on Meta\u2019s efforts to mitigate impersonation
column26: bullying and harassment on our platform
column27: and share the tools and resources available for you to help make Meta safer for all.Visit the Safety & Well-being hub5. Help fight the spread of misinformation Misinformation can be hard to spot
column28: but a few simple actions can help identify content that\u2019s been manipulated or taken out of context:1. Look up the source to check if it\u2019s credible2. Read the whole article
column29: not just the headline3. Find other sources for this informationAcross Meta\u2019s platforms
column30: independent
column31: third-party fact-checkers review and rate potential misinformation. These non-partisan fact-checkers evaluate problematic content across our apps
column32: which reduces the spread of viral misinformation and provides users with reliable information.This process provides labels if content is fact-checked and labeled as False
column33: Altered
column34: Partly False or Missing Context. However
column35: fact-checkers do not remove content
column36: accounts or Pages from Facebook. We remove content when it violates our Community Standards
column37: which is separate from our fact-checking program.Learn more about Meta\u2019s third-party fact-checking program here."}

column3: "title": "Impulso Local's new edition offers training and funding for Argentine media"

"title": "The power of earning: how Abud Sadek built his business on Facebook | Meta for Creators"
column7: "post_text": "Like many others it was during the pandemic in 2020 that Sadek discovered the opportunity to create and monetize his videos on Facebook. In two short years
column8: his Page now stands at over 5.4 million followers*! \u201cI have no doubt at all that Facebook holds the greatest opportunity for content creators
column9: \u201d he says.* Source: Sadek\u2019s Facebook page on August 16
column10: 2022Using income he made through monetizing on Facebook
column11: Abud was able to purchase his parents their dream house! That moment was eternalized in one of his most touching videos
column12: which already has over 47 million views on his page on the platform. Abud first started producing videos online back in 2014
column13: inspired by the prank-style videos that were popular in the United States at that time. He noticed that he was doing well as a content curator
column14: with videos reaching millions of viewers. But something very important was missing: he was having trouble turning those views into sustainable income.At that point
column15: Facebook caught his eye
column16: and the other creators making content specifically for the platform. \"I saw this foreign content and said 'there's something here!' I started to make content adapted for Facebook
column17: taking the algorithm into account
column18: and I stopped replicating videos from other platforms. When the first video hit two million views
column19: what I thought was: \u2018I'm rich!\u2019\u201d One of Sadek's most admirable characteristics is his ability to analyze other content and find creative and strategic opportunities to deliver relevant content to his own audience. \"There wasn't an influencer in Brazil that produced content designed for Facebook. That's how I started: observing international content that was getting a lot of views
column20: and realizing that there was an opportunity over here\". He adds: \"My life really turned over a new leaf since the first month on Facebook. Today
column21: 98% of my income comes from the platform.\"All results are self-reported and not identically repeatable. Generally expected individual results will differ.5 tips & tricks from Abud1Watch the numbers: What makes a video work? It\u2019s how it starts
column22: it\u2019s the click-through rate
column23: it\u2019s the engagement. I tried to study that
column24: to get themes that represented the audience that was watching me. I am a \u2018numbers freak\u2019. Who is my audience? Who is engaged? Who is watching me for more than one minute? Which age range is it? I started studying the Creator Studio insights a lot.2Know your audience: Representationis fundamental. Get to know your audience and understand which themes drive connection and identification. I always look for the broadest subjects possible and ideas that generate interest and represent my audience the most. Recipe videos with products that are in the Brazilian\u2019s daily life; me cleaning a pan with a formula I saw on the Internet; the comparison between the most expensive hamburger in Brazil and the cheapest one \u2013 all these videos have got millions of views.3Creator Studio is your best friend: I wouldn\u2019t exist if it wasn\u2019t for Creator Studio. It\u2019s a compass that points in the direction to follow. What works for me with each video is looking at the retention
column25: the audience loyalty
column26: but overall
column27: what makes sense to me is the \u20183-to-1 ratio\u2019: how many people who have watched the video for three seconds have also watched it for one minute? I often notice a greater chance of my video going viral if that ratio is closer to 50%.\u201d4Consistency: We are posting an average of four videos a day
column28: two of which are three minutes long and the other two are Reels. We realized that the Reels format attracts a lot of new people. We started to get a higher number of unique views and the number of followers had also increased because of the consistency of posting Reels. Also
column29: we realized that it is possible to monetize a lot using the Lives
column30: which have earned us about three times as much as the three-minute videos.(See how to earn money with your content on Facebook)5Be patient: There\u2019s a development period and you must understand that things won\u2019t change overnight. Make videos for three
column31: four
column32: five months. Use Creator Studio
column33: learn from your mistakes
column34: improve your videos constantly and learn from those who succeeded before you. Look at these people from a creator\u2019s perspective. Get inspired
column35: use references
column36: and then do it your own way.When reflecting on his future as a creator on Facebook
column37: Sadek is excited to see all the opportunity there is on the platform. He sees Reels\u2019 short video format as a great way to achieve his goals. \u201cWith Reels
column38: you can be recommended in the language in which you are creating your content. Today
column39: my main goal is to make my content international and create a network with people who share interests\u201d
column40: concludes the creator.See how to make your content profitable with the free course Monetizing Your Content on Facebook: What You Need to Know."}

column3: "title": "A creator\u2019s guide to growth: how to get your content seen on Facebook | Meta for Creators"
column7: "post_text": "What do you need to get started?All you need to be a creator is a Facebook account. On Facebook
column8: it is important to make sure you\u2019re using our most up-to-date Creator tools. If you are creating from a Page
column9: make sure you\u2019re on the New Page Experience. If you create content on a Profile
column10: you can transition to Professional Mode (only available in US
column11: Canada
column12: Mexico
column13: India
column14: Bangladesh
column15: Brazil
column16: and Indonesia). Both these experiences will give you the tools
column17: insights and tips you need to help grow as a Creator and continue to get updated with additional features over time.What is distribution and how to get your content seen on Facebook?As a creator
column18: it is important to understand the process of getting your content seen. In its simplest form
column19: distribution is the Facebook process of matching users with content they find engaging
column20: entertaining and informative.At Facebook
column21: we do this by asking four questions:1What content has been posted? What posts are available from friends
column22: other creators and Pages that we can show?2Who might like this content? We consider a multitude of signals such as who posted the content
column23: when it was posted
column24: what was the topic and past user behavior
column25: among others.3How likely are people to engage with the post? We try to predict how likely a given person is to engage with your post and find it meaningful. We make a variety of these predictions for each piece of content.4How interested will the audience be in this post? Based on all of the data we have gathered on the post
column26: which pieces of content should get priority? We follow these four steps for every piece of content
column27: for each person
column28: every time they open Facebook. There are two ways your content can be seen on Facebook:Connected Distribution: Your posts are seen by those who follow you on Facebook. This is your core audience on the platform.Unconnected Distribution: Your posts are seen by those who don\u2019t follow you
column29: but may be interested in your content. This type of distribution can come through other users sharing and resharing your posts or from our recommendations in our \u201cSuggested for You\u201d sections.Facebook initially started as a way to connect exclusively with your friends and family \u2013 connected distribution. Now
column30: we enable you to reach a much wider audience to help you grow beyond the sphere of those you know directly \u2013 unconnected distribution. To fully take advantage of unconnected distribution
column31: try optimizing your content in three specific ways:1Make Original Content: Creators receive the greatest distribution when they primarily post content that is filmed or created by them. Original content contains your unique voice and demonstrates the unique perspective you bring to Facebook. Original content is distinctive
column32: engaging
column33: and is what our users prefer.2Optimize for shares: Make content that other users want to share. This kind of content can spark meaningful dialogue
column34: respectful discussion and attracts more likes and reactions.3Get Recommended: Make sure your content complies with our  integrity rules and guidelines for recommended content. These guidelines outline what we will and won\u2019t recommend. Many creators focus on growing their following on Facebook. True growth
column35: however
column36: comes when you reach your following and maximize your ability to get reshared and find fans you didn\u2019t even know existed. To recap:When in doubt
column37: start with Reels. Reels are a great way to reach new fans. Create content authentic to yourself that engages your fans. Original
column38: engaging and meaningful content can help you to reach new fans and grow your audience. Measure your results frequently to see what is working and where you can improve. "}

column3: "title": "Announcing Dale T\u00fa
column4: Instagram\u2019s Latinx and Hispanic Creator Program | Meta for Creators"
column8: "post_text": "Dale T\u00fa (pronounced: dah-ley-too) aims to help creators build sustainable businesses and spark creativity by fostering a safe and inclusive community where they can thrive. Launching with an initial 2-month ambassador program
column9: Dale T\u00fa will offer extensive resources
column10: support and networking opportunities for Latinx and Hispanic creators to pursue their passions and let their creativity shine at scale.Our commitment to Latinx & Hispanic creatorsWe\u2019re proud to continue the journey of leveraging the power of social media on behalf of racial and social justice for diverse communities. These talented storytellers and changemakers are at the forefront of moving the needle on culture and championing the community. Through this program
column11: ambassadors will gain access to future-ready tools that encourage innovation
column12: create sustainable economic opportunities
column13: and can help take their brands to the next level.This is just the start and we know we have much more work ahead of us. We look forward to providing more opportunities to amplify a broad range of voices
column14: support creators as they gain insight into their businesses and content
column15: and build inclusive places for their creativity to thrive. Welcome to Dale T\u00fa.Visit the application page to learn about eligibility and how you can apply."}

column3: "title": "Meta signs commercial innovation deals with New Zealand publishers | Meta Journalism Project"
"title": "How Jomboy Media
column4: a Facebook page with less than one million followers
column5: consistently drives six-figure revenue | Meta for Creators"
column8: "url": "https://www.facebook.com/creators/jomboy-media"
column9: "post_text": "ResultsSix figures in revenue earned via in-stream ads in 2021220M+ monetized 1-min Facebook video views in 202185%+ of total Facebook video views in 2021 came from non-followers of Jomboy Media\u2019s pageOpportunity:Sports digital media company Jomboy Media (JM) has developed a robust in-stream ads business with only 915K Facebook followers
column10: earning six figures in net revenue over the past year. By developing an online community with a dedicated fanbase
column11: JM displays how a media company can drive tremendous in-stream earnings with original content. JM\u2019s early success can be attributed to:Developing premium
column12: owned IPIdentifying a content style that further enhances community among fansCultivating a roster of talent and creatorsAs media companies increasingly emphasize short-form video to meet booming demand
column13: JM is aiming to develop a short-form video strategy that can ladder up to its larger revenue goals.Strategy:Jomboy Media was founded by creator and public figure Jimmy \u201cJomboy\u201d O\u2019Brien in 2017. The company originally focused on baseball content
column14: recognizing that the sport wasn\u2019t well-covered on social media in a youth-oriented way. By leveraging a unique voice and developing owned IP
column15: Jomboy Media has cultivated a loyal fanbase that in turn drives viewership for its new
column16: original content projects.Through these original content franchises \u2013 and the returning audiences they drive \u2013 JM is widening its scope to generate strong Reels plays on Instagram
column17: impressive in-stream ads revenue on Facebook
column18: and a merchandise business that is poised to succeed via Instagram Checkout.JM\u2019s community-based social strategy centers on the following:Develop premium
column19: owned IPJM invested in an original content studio
column20: which the company has leveraged to create an original
column21: owned-IP powerhouse. So far
column22: JM has gone beyond baseball to develop creator-driven sports leagues around Blitzball
column23: golf
column24: hockey and cricket.The company\u2019s Blitzball league \u2013 and its main attraction
column25: the Blitzball Battle for $10
column26: 000 \u2013 helps JM build its audience and its bottom line through its utilization of:Branded content: JM secured a series-long partnership with DraftKings.Original IP: JM converted a warehouse into a functional arena for Blitzball and other sports
column27: which it uses to film games and short-form videos.Creator partnerships: JM connected with relevant creators to join the league as players alongside JM\u2019s own talent. The creators promote the content on their personal channels as well
column28: further broadening the league\u2019s reach.Reels
column29: Reels
column30: Reels: JM repurposes the full games as short-form clips for social
column31: distributed via their dedicated Instagram through Reels.Product promotion: JM promotes the series through Instagram Collabs with the larger Jomboy Media channel to drive additional viewership.Identify a content style that resonates with your audienceJM\u2019s original series use similar thematic through-lines and a consistent tone
column32: which helps the content resonate with fans who are in turn more likely to tune in across the JM content ecosystem. At scale
column33: these videos thrive across Facebook and Instagram because they:Capture attention: The opening 3 seconds always involve a direct
column34: table-setting comment to stir emotion.Inspire community: Comment sections and fan discussions around JM content develop a kinship among viewers
column35: which prompts return viewership and a desire to dive deeper into the wider JM content web.Promote virality: All content is filmed in near real-time to maximize cultural relevance.One series
column36: called \u201cBreakdowns\u201c
column37: utilizes Jimmy\u2019s unique approach to storytelling
column38: combined with his original voice
column39: insight and lip-reading commentary edited in an entertaining
column40: informative style to break down the latest in sports and pop culture.Cultivating community through talent & creatorsEach creator in the JM talent network has their own set of dedicated fans. By unifying the content under the larger Jomboy Media banner
column41: these individual fan communities form a larger
column42: stronger community across the JM network.JM has worked with these creators to build a network of O&O podcasts that were originally distributed as audio-only but are now optimized for video as well. Podcasts that have since become original video series include:Talkin\u2019 YanksThe Chris Rose RotationTalkin\u2019 BaseballMost of these shows are recorded and distributed using Facebook and Instagram Live
column43: with top clips repurposed as short-form video. This approach works well to increase audience engagement and rewatchability through:Personality-driven content: A network of owned creators allows for individual audience development and subject-matter diversity.Promotion of community: All JM content features calls-to-action for viewers to engage not just with the content
column44: but with each other \u2013 promoting further discourse among Jomboy Media fans.Creator-first focus: In the \u201cage of creators
column45: \u201d JM is driving top-line
column46: company-wide revenue through creator-built tools like Instagram Checkout and Collabs.Consistent content themes: Through unified editing techniques
column47: an adherence to timely / newsworthy content and a similar brand of humor
column48: JM\u2019s different creators foster content familiarity with audiences.The future: Doubling down on short-form videoTo continue diversifying its revenue and distribution models
column49: JM has committed to a content strategy that favors short-form video for the long-term. By leveraging unconnected audiences across Facebook and Instagram
column50: JM can then drive viewers into its long-form revenue funnel to more efficiently capture monetized content views."}

column3: "title": "Understanding Video Distribution on Facebook"
"title": "Reels help Thai creator Nanake diversify his content strategy | Meta for Creators"
column8: Nanake achieved:Generated over 74M Reels plays (1st May - 27th Jul) Over 50% of new followers came from Reels Nanake is a Thai star renowned for being the first to master the latest trends and products on social media
column9: primarily Facebook. When Reels launched in early 2022
column10: Nanake jumped at the chance to diversify his content strategy and try this new format.Naked Daily is bornIn early 2022
column11: Nanake launched Naked Daily: A Reels lifestyle show
column12: published daily on Facebook and Instagram. This video series
column13: targeted at young adults
column14: brings Nanake fans behind the scenes of his day-to-day life.Throughout the series
column15: fans have joined family celebrations including his Mum\u2019s birthday; celebrated his book launch; taken a tour of Nanake\u2019s collections
column16: including his car collection and his cool bookshelf; and met some of his famous friends.Fans have even watched Nanake solve puzzles. Check out this puzzle solving Reel with over 5M plays:Si \u00e8 verificato un erroreStiamo riscontrando problemi con la riproduzione di questo video.Scopri di pi\u00f9Nanake\u2019s Reels advice Be open to new experiences. Always be willing to try new things - like Reels - this is where the opportunities are.Never do the same thing expecting the same results. People change
column17: platforms change - be ready to adopt new ways. Make Reels that are fun
column18: original and authentic. Just be yourself and give it a try.Fan-driven content calendarNanake enjoys a strong connection with his fans
column19: which informs the Naked Daily content calendar. A reel showcasing what he\u2019s watching on TV and another displaying his car collection were created in response to fan questions or comments.\u201cMost of my Naked Daily reels answer common questions from fans and followers. They write to me seeking advice or request that I teach them certain skills
column20: \u201d says Nanake. \u201cThese quick answers make great reels and help my fans learn new life skills!\u201dWhen he\u2019s not responding to fan questions
column21: episodes are often crafted in response to his daily routine
column22: showcasing hobbies and daily tasks. Diversifying content
column23: format and toneOver the past few years
column24: Nanake mastered long-form video content. He is famed for his videos that deliver life advice from experts: including financial advice
column25: sexual health guidance and more. As the host of these important conversations
column26: his long-form content positions Nanake as the conduit between his fans and experts.Reels has allowed Nanake to diversify his content type and tone. Commercially
column27: Reels present a new
column28: more affordable format for brands to collaborate with the star. Reels is where Nanake gets personal
column29: he speaks directly to his fans and provides behind-the-scenes access to his private life.\u201cOur content plan for 2022 centered around problem solving for my fans
column30: \u201d said Nanake. \u201cI\u2019m interested in the generation gap
column31: inequalities in society
column32: the environment and the lifestyle of people with unresolved issues.\u201dNanake remains focused on the core DNA of his brand and Facebook Page
column33: which is about having a more enjoyable life.Naked Daily is Nanake\u2019s casual content format: intimate
column34: relaxed and personal Reels crafted by Nanake for his fans. These videos sit in contrast to his longer form videos which feature more structured conversations and are more elaborate.Original
column35: authentic content shinesSome of the most successful editions of Naked Daily have been the most authentic.Fans have embraced this spontaneous sharing
column36: with the star often grabbing his phone and recording the show on-the-go. In one Reel
column37: with over 8Mplays
column38: he sits in front of his phone and captures his hair and makeup routine.In another
column39: Nanake shares tips on tying a tie - a reel that has earned over 1.8M plays.Si \u00e8 verificato un erroreStiamo riscontrando problemi con la riproduzione di questo video.Scopri di pi\u00f9Collaboration is keyNanake is the star of Naked Daily
column40: but he\u2019s often sharing the spotlight with a famous friend. He understands that collaboration brings new opportunities and a fresh perspective for his audience.Serving audiences across Meta platformsNanake is focused on building a following across Facebook and Instagram. To serve both his audiences
column41: he posts his Naked Daily reels on both Facebook and Instagram. This allows him to widen his distribution
column42: maximizing efficiency.Catch the latest episodes of Naked Daily here"}

column3: "title": "How MONO29 shifted to a Reels-first social strategy"
"title": "Hop on trends and lead with emotion: More Reels advice from We The Culture creators | Meta for Creators"
column7: "post_text": "EDMOND ANYIRAH\u201cReels is my primary focus when it comes to Instagram
column8: \u201d said digital creator and animator Edmond Anyirah

Results are not identically repeatable and generally expected individual results will differ.*Timeframe indicative of when partner started posting Facebook Reels.Meta: You\u2019ve grown your Facebook page by over 1M followers in the last six months (over 8X). To what do you attribute this phenomenal growth?Rodriguez: Once Facebook launched Reels
column12: I was able to repurpose some of the short-form
column13: viral content I had created for other platforms such as Instagram Reels. Posting my content allowed me to reach a new
column14: and fast growing
column15: audience; I am super grateful for that.Similarly
column16: you added over 660K new followers to your Instagram over the same time period (+21%). To what do you attribute that growth?In August 2020
column17: I started filming my art process and began posting my subway creations on Instagram Reels. It\u2019s a pretty consistently viral format
column18: even if views fluctuate from reel to reel. Ever since then
column19: every single month there\u2019s been so much growth. These last six months? I guess I got lucky.What is your Reels strategy?Posting consistently. I try to post 3-5 times a week.Repeating a format that works. I always drew portraits
column20: even before creating video content
column21: as it\u2019s my passion to draw and capture as many people as I can through art. There\u2019s some luck with my format being a viral format that can be repeated that the algorithm loves
column22: so it sort of ties hand and hand with my art practice. If it ain\u2019t broke
column23: don\u2019t fix it. Good hook. I add a text overlay that says
column24: \u201cGiving a stranger a drawing of themselves\u201d so that immediately a viewer is hooked and curious. Then two seconds in
column25: I type out \u201cWait for their reaction\u201d so that the viewer knows that I\u2019ll give the drawing to the subject
column26: which keeps them watching. Delayed gratification. After the \u201cWait for their reaction\u201d text overlay
column27: I insert nine seconds of the drawing process. Within those nine seconds I make sure that every second is satisfying to watch and that the drawing looks just like the person that I presented to the viewer. Also
column28: I want to make sure that each second contains a huge progression in the drawing that impresses the viewer and keeps them intrigued throughout. The nine seconds of drawing gives me lots of watch-time before they get the gratification of the subject\u2019s reaction. Emotions. Viral content typically evokes high-arousal emotions
column29: such as joy or laughter. The act of drawing a stranger and making them feel seen often evokes lots of emotions in the receiver and the viewer. You post often across multiple platforms. Can you share your distribution cadence and
column30: being super active
column31: how you avoid burnout?I try to post 3-5 times a week on all of the major platforms. I find that all social media platforms prioritize watch-time as the most important factor for going viral and my content works pretty well on all of them. I really love what I do so I don\u2019t get burnt out too often but whenever I do
column32: I just take a break or try to outsource work
column33: like video editing. I created a Spanish Instagram account and for that
column34: I hired a friend to get the videos translated and manage the account. I\u2019d probably burn out if I added more to my plate. I try to keep things simple. I really love what I do so I don\u2019t get burnt out too often but whenever I do
column35: I just take a break or try to outsource work
column36: like video editing.@devonrodriguezartWhat is the idea behind your Spanish account
column37: @devonrodriguez_espanol?A lot of people enjoy my content
column38: but I realized that it\u2019s only understandable to English-speaking people which limits who can fully enjoy them. I figured I\u2019d get them translated to Spanish to build up a wider audience and eventually add on more languages.You recently shared in the media that you earned $500K through brand deals in 2021. How do you approach sponsored content on Instagram and Facebook?When I first started making video content
column39: my goal wasn\u2019t to do brand deals. I didn\u2019t even know that that was a possibility with art content
column40: I thought that was only for traditional influencers. My goal was to show the world what I do and hopefully grow an audience so that I can make a full-time living through selling my art.Brands started to approach me after amassing an audience in the millions on social media. I try to mix the brand\u2019s creative ideas with my art
column41: while keeping things organic
column42: and getting the brand as many views as possible. One of my favorites was when I collaborated with a popular gum brand and drew a portrait on a gum wrapper
column43: then gifted it to a person on the subway.The community you have cultivated across Meta platforms is so positive
column44: uplifting and encouraging. How do you foster that type of engagement? What tools do you use to weed out negativity?My content is really wholesome
column45: positive and joyful
column46: so positive people naturally gravitate to it. I rarely get negative comments on Facebook. On Instagram
column47: I sometimes restrict people that leave negative comments.Those people still follow me and I don\u2019t want to block them from seeing my videos just because they comment negatively. It does satisfy me to know that they think people see their negative comments
column48: but only they see them.One of your recent Reels from VidCon amassed over 59M plays on Instagram and over 8M plays on Facebook. Why do you think it took off the way it did?I did a drawing of one of the fastest growing creators on the internet right now
column49: who\u2019s been commanding a lot of attention. I thought it would be fun for people to see his reaction to it. I filmed his reaction at VidCon and the reel went really viral! That one reel has gotten me 100K new Instagram followers.People love seeing people\u2019s reactions to drawings of them in general
column50: and when you add their favorite creators or celebrities into the mix
column51: it just adds that extra layer of excitement.What advice do you have for fellow creators who would like to grow a loyal community on Facebook and Instagram?Stick to what you love so that it doesn\u2019t become work. Experiment with all kinds of content and editing formats. Find what works
column52: then be consistent. Find creative ways to maximize watch-time.Stick to what you love so that it doesn\u2019t become work. Experiment with all kinds of content and editing formats. Find what works
column53: then be consistent. Find creative ways to maximize watch-time.@devonrodriguezartDevon Rodriguez\u2019s Top Reels Tips:1Post consistently. 2Experiment with different format and content types
column54: then repeat the ones that work. 3Hook the viewer in right away. A good hook keeps them watching. 4Tease what\u2019s to come
column55: then delay gratification. 5Evoke emotions such as joy
column56: surprise and excitement. 6Foster a positive community through positive content. "}
