"title": "93M Reels Plays in 6 months: Why Nicholas Crown tests everything
column4: all the time | Meta for Creators"
column8: "post_text": "Results120K new Instagram followers
column9: 1/1/2022-7/1/2022 (+86%)100 Instagram Reels published 1/1/2022-7/1/202293M+ Instagram Reels Plays
column10: 1/1/2022-7/1/2022250K plays on average from unconnected audiences \u2014 i.e.
column11: people that don\u2019t yet follow Crown\u2019s account According to publicly available data from CrowdTangle and Meta. Results are not identically repeatable and generally expected individual results will differ.StrategyCrown\u2019s Instagram Reels are a form of social commentary told through two recurring characters: Mr. Rich and Mr. Really Rich. He constructs everyday scenarios with humor and always leaves viewers with something to ponder
column12: be it lessons on humility and kindness or advice on how to think conceptually about wealth. He posts three new reels every week (down from five) interspersed with static quote cards that tie directly to the messaging he shares in Reels. Those quote cards are on their way to becoming Reels themselves\u2013with voice over\u2013 as the format opened up growth and monetization opportunities for Crown the likes of which he hasn\u2019t seen elsewhere.Test
column13: iterate
column14: repeatAt the core of Crown\u2019s strategy is his ability to test dozens of variations in both content and format
column15: learn quickly what resonates and implement those learnings in subsequent posts. This strategy grew his follower base on Instagram by 86% in only six months.When it comes to testing content
column16: Crown has a character trait matrix for both Rich and Really Rich. This allows him to explore and expand how each approaches situations while remaining true to who they are as characters. \u201cThe audience will call you out if your character is out of step
column17: \u201d he cautioned. Having the characters nailed is important
column18: he explained. As in baking
column19: all the ingredients have to be right to make a cake. It doesn\u2019t matter what the cake looks like as long as the right ingredients are there.When it comes to format
column20: or \u201cwhat the cake looks like
column21: \u201d Crown tests everything from length to headline design
column22: subtitles design
column23: intros and more. And just as in business
column24: Crown compared
column25: \u201cthe market gives you feedback if things are headed in the right direction.\u201d Similarly on Instagram
column26: \u201cyou know pretty quickly if something is going to catch on.\u201d In this testing framework
column27: Crown pays attention to every reel\u2019s initial velocity. For about an hour after posting
column28: he checks in on the post to see whether it\u2019s taking off and how people are commenting. This hyper-testing mentality has the added benefit of keeping things interesting for both Crown and his audience \u201cwhile challenging myself
column29: \u201d he added.Old content can be new againOne recent test Crown deployed involved repackaging older content for a new and potentially unconnected audience (i.e. an audience that doesn\u2019t yet follow him and encounters his content through the Reels tab
column30: Explore page or through shares). \u201c50% of my impressions come from an unconnected audience
column31: \u201d said Crown. He\u2019s been tacking on an intro to older reels that explain to viewers in under 3 seconds what they are about to watch
column32: thus increasing the chance they\u2019ll stick around to watch it.Another test he recently ran involved a CTA (call-to-action) at the end of reels. He realized that reels with a CTA didn\u2019t perform the way he had hoped so he archived them and re-edited to remove the CTA. Those reels performed significantly better. \u201cPeople don\u2019t want to leave the platform
column33: I take the viewing experience into consideration
column34: \u201d he remarked.Generally speaking
column35: if a post hasn\u2019t broken 200K-300K plays after a week
column36: it\u2019s a contender for archiving and revisiting later
column37: he said.Perform regular health checksCrown checks his insights regularly as part of his testing and iteration framework. But his checks go beyond \u201ccommon\u201d KPIs to determine correlation between content
column38: format and growth.\u201cFirst
column39: I do damage control to see what might have lost me followers
column40: \u201d he shared. While he\u2019s aware that a new follower count can fluctuate
column41: \u201cI want to see a growth curve
column42: a consistent upward trend.\u201d Everyone should perform \u201ca health check on your account to make sure everything is moving in the right direction
column43: \u201d he advised.Quarterly
column44: he orders his top performing posts by Shares and by Engagement to see \u201cwhat\u2019s driving the most meaningful action on the platform
column45: \u201d then he thinks through why those top performers resonated.Understand what makes Reels uniqueCrown has found that the audience on Reels
column46: when compared to audiences on non-Meta platforms
column47: \u201cunderstands the episodic nature of skits and returns day after day
column48: week after week.\u201d Very quickly
column49: he said
column50: he had a core audience that was following along
column51: expecting new content and asking engaging questions. Discoverability also became meaningful very fast
column52: he added. \u201cReels was the tool that brought engagement and audience growth in a meaningful and compelling way
column56: as organic reach is high on branded content. \u201cThere\u2019s small audience crossover with other channels. The audience on Reels really is unique which makes it a valuable channel for advertisers.\u201d Reels was the tool that brought engagement and audience growth in a meaningful and compelling way.Nicholas CrownThere\u2019s money out there
column57: but play it smartBrands have a lot of money earmarked for Reels
column58: making this moment in time an opportune one for Reels creators
column59: said Crown. But working with brands isn\u2019t one size fits all. It\u2019s important for creators to accept deals that make sense for them and to negotiate when things don\u2019t feel right.\u201cBrands usually treat your first unit as a test\u201d and a creator\u2019s goal is to move into a multi-unit deal
column60: Crown explained. Often brands test a \u201clarge basket of creators. If you deliver consistent results
column61: you\u2019re a professional and you take this job seriously
column62: you\u2019ll have a long term partner that understands the economics around it in a fair and balanced way.\u201d It\u2019s a serious job to communicate a product in the right way
column64: and \u201cbrands are seeking creators who are uniquely equipped to talk about certain topics.\u201d That said
column65: some brands might come in low when they first show interest. For many creators
column66: those offers are exciting and many are quick to take them. But \u201cbe really wary of early deals
column67: \u201d Crown cautioned. \u201cHold out for the right brands
column71: Crown noted. Make sure you know what you are giving up in exchange for money. Remember that as a creator
column72: you can change the game on what an ad feels like and can accomplish\u2013it\u2019s a powerful place to be. \u201cPlay the long game and make sure it\u2019s a fair exchange of value
column73: \u201d he advised. \u201cPatience pays off.\u201dMake sure you know what you are giving up in exchange for money. Remember that as a creator
column74: you can change the game on what an ad feels like and can accomplish\u2013it\u2019s a powerful place to be. Play the long game and make sure it\u2019s a fair exchange of value. Patience pays off.Nicholas CrownConsider reinvesting in your businessOnce brand deals are inked
column75: creators either invest in themselves and their business or they impulsively buy a new car
column76: Crown jokingly observed. He chose the former. Reinvesting in himself has enabled him to deliver higher quality content and diversify into other verticals
column78: and enabled him to show more of his lifestyle.Whereas initially he wrote
column79: shot and edited every video himself
column80: he now has a small team that consists of a videographer/photographer for lifestyle content and heavy editing
column81: and an editor \u201cfor quick stuff.\u201d\u201cTake all the money and stick it back into the machine
column83: \u201creinvest in the team to broaden your capabilities and attract more brands.\u201d Scaling is a powerful way to combat burnout
column85: you have to figure out the lightest way to get your face on there without driving yourself insane.\u201dDon\u2019t be afraid to diversify and branch outWhile focusing on your niche is important
column86: creators should aim to \u201cdiversify as you scale to give people reason to stick around
column87: \u201d Crown said. He\u2019s done so himself
column88: branching into lifestyle content. \u201cAs a creator
column89: it\u2019s up to you to show that you are three dimensional. Everyone has strong suits beyond their flagship content.\u201d Maybe you do skits
column91: you\u2019re a comedian but you\u2019re also good at tennis
column92: Crown said. You\u2019re a unique person and you\u2019re making yourself irreplaceable when you combine those different aspects of your life. Be someone that someone is interested to check in with. Audiences may be surprised and excited to find out more about you. Particularly in comedy
column94: if people can\u2019t sink their teeth into you as a person they will lose interest and move on because \u201cthat foundation-building to connect as a person isn\u2019t there.\u201d\u201cInvest in verticals that don't show immediate return but build your brand. I\u2019m showing measured
column95: additional sides of me that make sense as part of the whole pie. Creators who do that will have longevity.\u201dYou\u2019re a unique person and you\u2019re making yourself irreplaceable when you combine different aspects of your life. Be someone that someone is interested to check in with. Audiences may be surprised and excited to find out more about you.Nicholas CrownScale
column96: find efficiencies and keep goingCrown is not only diversifying his content verticals but has his mind set on increasing his output
column97: too. The challenge then becomes maintaining his high quality standard at a much larger volume
column98: though that would enable him to reach a wider audience and secure mainstream deals with big multinational partners.\u201cFind the scalable kernel in your content
column99: \u201d he advised others who may want to do the same
column100: and then figure out how to build up
column101: either by bringing on a team or by batching.Investing heavily in his brand and infusing more of himself into his content
column103: \u201cbuilds trust. It\u2019s a longevity play.\u201d Outside of Instagram but entirely related
column104: Crown is \u201cbuilding a financial mindset app and working to democratize certain financial products to support the community that I built on Reels
column105: \u201d another long-term vision.Nicholas Crown\u2019s Top Tips: 1Test everything: your content
column109: etc.2Pay attention to insights in the short- and long-term. Initial velocity is an indicator of how your Reel is being received but give it a week to breathe.3Be wary of early brand deals and always read through contracts. Make sure brand deals you sign offer a fair exchange of value.4Reinvest in your business which will help you diversify and scale.5Branch out
column110: show different facets of your personality and your life. People connect to people."}

column3: "title": "\u201cDo not equate numbers with success
column4: \u201d and more advice from social media guru Candace Marie | Meta for Creators"
column8: "post_text": "Don\u2019t get attached to social media numbers
column9: advised Candace Marie. As long as you love the content you\u2019re putting out
column10: that\u2019s all that matters. \u201cThe No. 1 lesson: Do not equate numbers with success
column11: \u201d she shared with over 200 Black creators in attendance
column12: and many more joining virtually.To \"get past the numbers
column13: \" she shared four pieces of advice:Take breaks\u201cNothing about being burnt out or overworked is attractive
column14: \u201d Candace Marie paraphrased a post she had seen on one of her favorite Instagram accounts. Taking a break doesn't mean you're quitting
column15: she reminded her audience. Taking a break means you're avoiding a breakdown.Stop the comparison\u201cMute
column16: Unfollow
column17: Block whoever you need to
column18: \u201d she said. \u201cWhat is for you will always be for you. Don't be fooled
column19: everything on social media is not as it appears.\u201dFind your audience
column20: your community\u201cIf you try to make content for everybody
column21: you end up making content for nobody
column22: \u201d Candace Marie noted
column23: adding that @blckincorporate was founded with a hyper-targeted audience in mind. \u201cGo after your community and be specific.\u201dGet some perspective\u201cJust because your engagement isn\u2019t high
column24: doesn't mean you\u2019ve failed
column25: \u201d said Candace Marie. \u201cWe can\u2019t see who passively engages with our accounts. There are more eyeballs on your content than you know.\u201dAll it takes is the right person to see your content
column26: she added. If the right person sees your content
column27: that\u2019s all that matters.Candace Marie added that while her editorial background leans high gloss and her personal penchant is for photos
column28: she recognizes that \u201cReels is here to stay\u201d and as such
column29: she\u2019s making the medium work for her.\u201cLean into your individuality. It\u2019s possible to be on trend and be authentic to who you are
column30: \u201d Candace Marie advised. \u201cPractice patience
column31: not everything will happen instantly. Good things come to those who wait\u2013and create.\u201dCandace Marie\u2019s 9 Tips for Reels: 1Choose trending audio (indicated by an arrow).2Post at peak times but know that those can change.3Test out new content.4Look back to see what performs
column32: what resonates.5Don\u2019t overthink it. Simplicity and authenticity > polish and perfection.6Look to others for inspiration; remember to give credit where credit is due.7Engage with other content
column33: hype others up (Like
column34: share
column35: comment
column36: purchase).8The best camera is already in your hand; remember to wipe the lens clean.9Be open to change. You are ever evolving.Si \u00e8 verificato un erroreStiamo riscontrando problemi con la riproduzione di questo video.Scopri di pi\u00f9"}

column3: "title": "7 Tips & tricks for creators
column5: on working with brands | Meta for Creators"
column8: "url": "https://www.facebook.com/creators/creators-brand-deals-partnerships-advice"
column9: "post_text": "Deploy a multi-pronged approachLifestyle creator Luann Diez shared that she aims to show up in multiple touchpoints when she collaborates on brand campaigns. That means posting to Instagram Stories
column10: Feed and Reels.\u201cI try to target all the different tools that Instagram has so that it\u2019s a more beneficial campaign
column11: more authentic and more long-term \u2013 people don\u2019t just see it once and forget about it
column12: but they have a more long lasting effect on what you\u2019re trying to sell or the brand awareness that you want to create
column13: \u201d she said.Creator and founder of Smile Squad
column14: Markian Benhamou
column15: concurred. \u201cI use a lot of features when I\u2019m doing brand partnerships: I use video to make the main piece of content
column16: then Reels can be the one minute highlight of that content as a teaser. And then Stories really help with behind-the-scenes to inform viewers of what\u2019s going on. I love having kind of a multidimensional approach when making content with brands.\u201dShare your storyEveryone has their story
column17: every creator is on their own journey
column18: and tapping into that is invaluable when working with brands.\u201cI\u2019m Mexican and I live in the US
column19: \u201d shared Diez. \u201cI\u2019ve lived in the US for half of my life and I feel like a lot of people can relate to that story. They have lived this story and they can relate to me
column20: which creates kind of like a bond. And I think it can be very beneficial to brands to use my story.\u201dAlign your values\u201cWhen partnering with a brand
column21: it\u2019s important to know everything about them. I know that sounds like a lot
column22: but you need to know what they stand for
column23: \u201d said Diez. \u201cTheir work ethics are very important. What their messaging is for the campaign. You want to have good communication with them.\u201d You also want to find out \u201cwho are the other creators they associate with because you\u2019re not only associating yourself with that brand
column24: but the other creators that they work with as well.\u201dComedian and actress Daphnique Springs echoed that sentiment. \u201cI want to work with brands where I feel like they\u2019re trustworthy
column25: \u201d she said. \u201cThey\u2019re very clear on their message so that I can convey their message back to my audience. I love working with brands that are diverse
column26: that are very fluid and just relate to me and my people.\u201dMarkian added that the expectation goes both ways\u2013brands should research creators and take time to immerse in their communities to ensure values align on both sides. \u201cGet involved with the content
column27: learn about the community
column28: learn who the influential people are
column29: \u201d he advised brands. Forming a connection with a creator over shared values can help ensure that the resulting body of work resonates with their audience and leads to results.Leverage your insightsSprings shared that she leverages insights to showcase brands how engaged her audience is
column30: and that they are in the brand\u2019s target demographic.\u201cMeta is amazing at giving you precise analytics so that brands can know if you have the audience that they want to attract and work with
column31: \u201d said Springs. \u201cI\u2019m able to get the countries
column32: the age groups
column33: the genders. And all of that stuff is very important because a brand should not waste money on a creator that\u2019s not their target audience.\u201dConnect with brands IRL and onlineDiez shared that brands often slide into her DMs with proposals to collaborate
column34: and she has done the same with brands she admires. They also email her (Pro tip: Include an email address in your Instagram bio!) though her \u201cfavorite is definitely at events
column35: because you get to really meet the person that you\u2019re going to be working with and see if it would actually be a match to work on a campaign together.\u201dSurface brand-work to the topSprings said that the new grid pinning feature is going to take her brand partnerships to the next level because now
column36: branded posts will be highlighted at the top of her profile grid.\u201cEvery time someone comes to your profile
column37: they can now see that you\u2019re working with that brand
column38: \u201d she said
column39: adding that brands should bake the feature as a requirement into contracts.Remember your core strength\u201cBrands gain trust from creators
column40: \u201d said Markian. \u201cCreators have that authentic connection with their audience. Creators are people
column41: they have personalities. For us
column42: it\u2019s all about having a positive message with our content. If we can integrate a brand with that
column43: then it\u2019s gonna be a seamless collaboration.\u201dSprings reiterated the message
column44: saying that her connection to her audience is the superpower she brings to the table. Partnering with her
column45: \u201cyou\u2019re able to gain someone who truly knows their audience and has the creativity to attract their audience.\u201d"}

column3: "title": "Advice from nonprofits to creators who want to mobilize their communities | Meta for Creators"
column8: product manager at PushBlack
column9: a nonprofit media organization that focuses on Black history and mobilization; Tom D'Souza
column10: global innovation manager at Movember
column11: the world's largest men's health movement that focuses on mental health and suicide prevention in men
column12: prostate cancer and testicular cancer; Zack Flores
column13: senior director of marketing for Save The Music
column14: a national music education nonprofit; and Cubby Graham
column15: creator and social media lead at charity: water which brings clean
column16: safe drinking water to people who need it.Watch the session in full here and read highlights below.Jankowski: Talking about social issues can be really hard and challenging. How do you humanize them on social media? \u201cThere is a fine line when addressing hard issues
column17: \u201d said Flores
column18: \u201cbeing able to come off as authentic is really the key messaging. And by harnessing the power of storytelling
column19: that's one of the greatest opportunities to humanize hard-hitting issues and back that up with a call to action.\u201d  \u201cIt's also very important to consider investing in the long haul
column20: to continuously back up what you are saying on social media and keep audiences informed
column21: to really know and show that you are completely invested in the mission.\u201dGraham concurred
column22: adding that storytelling with dignity has been really important to charity: water from the very beginning.\u201cBeing able to show people the impact that their $40 can have in someone's life and being able to honor that person's story and the impact that it's having\u201d is a critical piece of the organization\u2019s social media strategy. \u201cIt also makes it really real when you can humanize a number. column3: "title": "Bright colors
column4: fun and peeks behind-the-scenes: Kelli Erdmann is all-in on Reels | Meta for Creators"
column8: "post_text": "Results75 Instagram Reels published between March 1
column10: and June 1
column11: 2022796M+ Instagram Reels Plays
column12: 3/1/2022-6/1/2022700K+ Instagram followers added
column13: 3/1/2022-6/1/2022According to publicly available data from CrowdTangle and Meta. Results are not identically repeatable and generally expected individual results will differ.Meta: You nearly doubled your Instagram following over the last 12 months
column14: attracting 700K new followers in the last three months alone (3/1/2022-6/1/2022). To what do you attribute this phenomenal growth?Kelli Erdmann: We have tried to post on Reels daily. Luckily some of our reels have resonated with people
column15: gotten a lot of views and that turned into fast growth.The last three months
column16: a few videos stand out as the main growth drivers: this making-of video got nearly 84M plays
column17: another one set to trending audio got over 77M plays and this behind-the-scenes peek leveraged as a teaser got over 55M plays.At the end of the day we try to just have fun with the videos we post and make things that make people smile! I think that the fun we have trickles through the screen.You\u2019ve gone all-in on Reels which means you don\u2019t post any other format (e.g. photos
column18: longer videos). What\u2019s behind that decision?We started making SFV (short-form video) early in the pandemic when we didn\u2019t have much else going on
column19: and decided to make fun videos to make people smile during a tough time. We\u2019ve really enjoyed making SFV content and haven\u2019t really branched into photography or long-form content so Reels are a natural place to post what we love creating.Reels attracted us because they can be shown to a much wider audience than just our followers. As a feature
column20: Reels has sparked our recent growth because of how powerful it is in reaching new audiences.Reels attracted us because they can be shown to a much wider audience than just our followers. As a feature
column21: Reels has sparked our recent growth because of how powerful it is in reaching new audiences.@kelladactylWhile you have previously peeled back the curtain on the making of your content
column22: in March 2022 you turned behind-the-scenes into a full-blown
column23: standalone content franchise. What has diversifying your content pillars afforded you?We realized that BTS (behind-the-scenes) videos are where people can really see how much fun we have making our videos. An added bonus with BTS is that it requires little additional work
column24: while doubling the amount of content we have ready to post.BTS has completely revitalized our page; we were stuck at the same level for a few months and when we started posting BTS
column25: it immediately started to grow again so we kept doing it.Some of your BTS reels have gotten incredible reach
column26: garnering over 70-80M+ plays each. In your analysis
column27: what made these particular reels such a hit?First
column28: I think whenever a video goes as viral as those went
column29: there is quite a bit of luck involved. That being said
column30: I think those reels in particular performed well because they were very happy
column31: fun
column32: short and used a very popular song.I think some of that reach can be attributed to the \u201cresults\u201d videos feeding into the \u201cBTS\u201d videos and vice versa
column33: but mostly it seems people thought it was funny to see a green man (or woman) being silly and they shared it
column34: watched and liked it.Si \u00e8 verificato un erroreStiamo riscontrando problemi con la riproduzione di questo video.Scopri di pi\u00f9Si \u00e8 verificato un erroreStiamo riscontrando problemi con la riproduzione di questo video.Scopri di pi\u00f9You\u2019ve adopted Instagram Collabs
column35: taking advantage of the feature that lets you tap into a collaborator\u2019s reach and engagement (and vice versa). What\u2019s your favorite part about the feature?I love that it allows creators who are already collaborating to post the video once and not have to fill our common followers\u2019 feeds with the same video multiple times.It also is a fun way to discover new creators or be discovered by a friend\u2019s audience. I personally love when a friend posts with someone that I don\u2019t know
column36: because I can discover that new person and see what they are doing more easily.Pro tip: Collabs is now available on Facebook
column37: enabling creators to tag other creators as collaborators on a single piece of content that will be published on both participants\u2019 Pages.[Collabs] is a fun way to discover new creators or be discovered by a friend's audience. I personally love when a friend posts with someone that I don't know
column38: because I can discover that new person and see what they are doing more easily.@kelladactylWhat is your production and programming schedule like?I wish we were organized enough to have dedicated days for shooting. We are typically working all day
column39: every day and doing whatever feels right that day. We kind of go with the flow because it\u2019s just me and my husband working together.Because we shoot nearly every day
column40: a lot of what we shoot never sees the light of day. It\u2019s a very inexact science. Sometimes we will stock up on content before we go on vacation
column41: but I feel like the best content comes when we are consistently creating and doing whatever we think is funny or fun on that particular day.You\u2019ve grown nearly 300% on Facebook over the last few months as well. To what do you attribute that growth?Our strategy on Facebook is to post whatever we are already posting on Instagram. We weren\u2019t posting there for a long time and figured if we are making content
column42: might as well post it wherever we can. While we don\u2019t have as big of a presence on Facebook
column43: our page is steadily growing and it\u2019s fun to see that growth.You\u2019ve been able to monetize your presence on Instagram primarily through brand deals. Can you speak to how you approach sponsored content?The majority of our brand deals come from inbound messages: Brands or ad agencies that have seen our profile and want to work with us.We try to only work on brand deals where we know we can make a creative video that fits well within our current feed. We like to keep our ads entertaining whenever possible. We also avoid advertising for things that we don\u2019t use. For example
column44: neither of us drinks alcohol so we don\u2019t advertise for alcohol brands.How often do you look at insights and how do those help inform your strategy?We look at insights probably too often. We want to make videos that we enjoy making
column45: but insights help inform us on what resonates with our audience. They are kind of the reason we started making BTS videos\u2013we saw that our audience enjoyed them so we just kept making them.What advice do you have for content creators who\u2019d like to grow a loyal community on Facebook & Instagram like you have?Make enjoying what you're making your biggest priority. Burnout can come fast but if you genuinely enjoy making the kind of videos you are creating
column46: it doesn't feel like work and people will want to watch along and have fun with you.Post consistently. Be consistent in the kind of content you post
column47: the quality and the frequency at which you post.Make enjoying what you're making your biggest priority. Burnout can come fast but if you genuinely enjoy making the kind of videos you are creating
column48: it doesn't feel like work and people will want to watch along and have fun with you.@kelladactylWhat\u2019s next for you?We feel very grateful to each of our followers; they make it possible for us to make fun silly videos for a living. Looking to the future
column49: we would love to delve into the e-commerce space and start to bring products that we love directly to our audience
column50: but haven't had time to commit and make that a reality.KELLI ERDMANN\u2019S TOP REELS TIPS1Have fun and try to make people smile.2Leverage Reels to reach an audience beyond your following.3Consider sharing the behind-the-scenes making of your content.4Trending audio can make your reels \u201cpop.\u201d5Use hashtags that are relevant to your post.6Insights can help inform on what resonates with your audience.7Be consistent in the kind of content you post
column51: the quality and the frequency."}

"title": "Reels gold at SEA Games 2022! | Meta for Creators"
column7: "post_text": "I reel stravincono ai SEA Games 2022I SEA Games 31 hanno rappresentato uno dei principali eventi culturali e sportivi del 2022 per il Sud-est asiatico (SEA). Pi\u00f9 di 4900 atleti provenienti da 11 Paesi SEA si sono riuniti in Vietnam. Questi supereroi si sono sfidati in pi\u00f9 di 500 eventi
column8: tutto per rendere orgoglio al loro Paese ed essere incoronati i migliori della regione.I giochi hanno riunito gli amanti dello sport
column9: offrendo esperienze online e offline volte a coinvolgere sia i fan in loco sia i tifosi a casa.I creator abbracciano lo spirito dei SEA GamesI tifosi e i follower sportivi a casa si sono riuniti grazie alle tecnologie di Meta. I creator hanno rappresentato la loro nazione partecipando a questo evento culturale e pubblicando reel a sostegno dalla loro squadra nazionale. Hanno utilizzato il filtro AR del loro Paese e hanno partecipato a un ballo virale che ha fatto furore nella regione nel maggio 2022
column10: garantendo ai creator pi\u00f9 di 45 milioni di visualizzazioni durante lo svolgimento dei giochi.Perch\u00e9 \u00e8 stato un successo per cos\u00ec tanti creator dell'area APAC? I creator hanno tifato la loro squadra nazionale realizzando reel con il filtro AR del loro Paese. In questo divertente reel

Quynh Alee ha dichiarato \"I miei reel dei SEA Games hanno avuto il numero maggiore di visualizzazioni.\"Raggiungere un nuovo pubblicoI reel rappresentano un potente strumento per ampliare la distribuzione dei contenuti e collegarsi con nuovi fan. column36: i creator sono stati in grado di aumentare il loro pubblico.Hoang Nam Ky Thu ha lavorato per creare una serie di reel (sei reel in 12 giorni) per interrogare il pubblico dei SEA Games sulle loro conoscenze sportive. Grazie alla partecipazione a questo evento e alla creazione di questi contenuti \u00e8 riuscito ad aumentare il suo pubblico.A maggio abbiamo raddoppiato il tasso di crescita durante la campagna dei SEA Games 31 grazie ai reel!Hoang Nam Ky ThuHai bisogno di ispirazione per i tuoi reel? Dai uno sguardo all'hashtag dei SEA Games #ReelsSEAGames31 per guardare tutti i reel dei giochi."}

column3: "title": "Meet the 2022 HBCU Summer News Fellows | Meta Journalism Project"
"title": "What creators and athletes can learn from snowboarder Scotty James \u2014 who used Instagram Reels to grow 45% in 12 months"
column7: "post_text": "Results95K+ Instagram followers added from February 2021 through February 2022 \u2014 45%+ overall growth in follower base*More than half of these followers added in January and February 2022 alone*65M+ Reels plays from February 2021 through February 202255M+ of these plays are from unconnected audiences \u2014 i.e.
column8: people that don\u2019t yet follow Scotty\u2019s account12x+ increase in Instagram video views comparing February 2021 through February 2022 vs. the previous 12-month period** According to public CrowdTangle dataOpportunity:Scotty James is a professional snowboarder whose honors to date include bronze and silver medals at the 2018 and 2022 Winter Games
column9: three world championships
column10: and four X Games golds. Born and raised in Australia
column11: Scotty now lives in London and competes around the world. It\u2019s crucial for him to use Instagram to reach his global fanbase with snowboard and lifestyle content
column12: so he can provide his followers a glimpse into his daily life and training regimen.With the launch of Reels on Instagram
column13: Scotty looked to utilize the short-form video format for the types of clips that work best on the platform \u2014 quick-hitters highlighting his incredible halfpipe tricks
column14: as well as behind-the-scenes moments that showcase his personality. He also saw an opportunity to leverage Reels for branded content and commercial posts with competition hosts and sponsors
column15: to further maximize the value these videos can drive.Strategy:Meta spoke with Scotty
column16: his head of content strategy Charlie Thomas
column17: and his brother
column18: videographer
column19: and creative director Sean James to learn how they think through Scotty\u2019s Instagram strategy to best grow his audience and engage followers. The trio
column20: along with social manager Oli Acutt
column21: forms a tight team that ensures the Scotty James brand wins online just as much as he does on the snow.What\u2019s a day in the life like when it comes to capturing footage of Scotty?Sean:\u201cMy strategy when I\u2019m out there with Scotty is to start rolling from the second he puts his boots on through when he takes them off at the end of the day. It\u2019s a combination of using different cameras and also iPhone. What I\u2019ve found from all this time filming him is the more you shoot
column22: the more you have access to later. We know we aren\u2019t going to use all of the footage
column23: but you don\u2019t know when you\u2019re going capture a great moment for social.\u201d\u201cSometimes athletes just want to focus on training and not outside content capturing
column24: so I really take a fly-on-the-wall approach
column25: where I\u2019m not seen
column26: not heard. Then at the end of the day when Scotty\u2019s like \u2018Did you get this shot?\u2019
column27: I can say \u2018Yeah I did\u2019 and he won\u2019t even realize I was shooting it. I\u2019ll use broadcast equipment to shoot from far away and put a mic on him
column28: so I can capture intimate moments where he\u2019s talking with his coach without being intrusive.\u201d\u201cAt the end of the day
column29: I dump all the footage onto my computer
column30: and Charlie and I figure out what types of social posts we want or need to focus on \u2014 whether we need to make branded posts with a sponsor
column31: or we have the freedom to put up whatever we want.\u201dScotty:\u201cI\u2019m in an amazing position to have a brother who is so incredible at video who is always with me. A lot of people say \u2018oh working with family
column32: that must be hard\u2019
column33: well we\u2019re two very different people
column34: but also very similar in what we want to accomplish. We\u2019re always brainstorming and feeling out ideas together
column35: it\u2019s a huge advantage.\u201d\u201cWe feel what people really crave is relatable content. So we always use our phones to film
column36: because at the end of the day
column37: people want to see things they can do themselves. We\u2019ve experimented by posting highly edited videos
column38: and also just posting videos recorded by phone straight to Reels. And the ones recorded by phone almost always do better. Which makes life easier as well.Si \u00e8 verificato un erroreStiamo riscontrando problemi con la riproduzione di questo video.Scopri di pi\u00f9You posted your first Reel on Instagram in February 2021 and haven\u2019t looked back. What attracted you to Reels?Charlie:\u201cReels seem to be a great way to reach new people that aren\u2019t yet followers of Scotty\u2019s account. Athletes want to grow and grow and strive for excellence in every facet of their life \u2014 so with Scotty
column39: it\u2019s a big focus for him
column40: being able to grow his social media following. Instagram is a platform where if someone young doesn\u2019t know who you are
column41: they aren\u2019t going to look you up elsewhere on the internet
column42: they\u2019ll first search your name on Instagram. Reels have been a huge driver of growth for Scotty on his Instagram \u2014 they allow Scotty to share his highlight moments in an off-the-cuff
column43: short-form way.\u201dSean:\u201cThe reason why we\u2019re so attracted to Reels is Scotty\u2019s sport is based around 30 seconds. He\u2019ll have a 30-second run
column44: and within that run
column45: the highlights are short bursts of action. We can go out and shoot one trick and turn that into a Reel \u2014 play it in real-time
column46: make it slow-mo
column47: edit it up. Reels seem to reward action footage well. The spectacle of what he does on a snowboard \u2014 the speed
column48: the amplitude
column49: the magnitude of these tricks \u2014 comes across really well as a short
column50: well-produced video.\u201d\u201cWhen Reels turned up
column51: so much of what we were already posting is now so much more rewarded on social. For us
column52: that makes us want to post more
column53: because we\u2019re getting so much out of it
column54: so many new eyes. For snackable content
column55: Reels have really been perfect for us since day one. They\u2019re fun too. The Reels feature is a lot of fun.\u201dScotty:\u201cWe love posting Reels because it gives us a platform to share with everyone what we\u2019re doing on a daily basis
column56: and we can do it in our own unique way \u2014 we can have a lot of fun with it. We\u2019ve gravitated more recently to following trends to inform our Reels
column57: which we weren\u2019t doing originally \u2014 but now we love incorporating trending themes and challenges into our Reels.\u201dI\u2019m always inclined to post Reels
column58: because Instagram has always been our north star in terms of using a platform. My sponsors
column59: who I partner with for branded content \u2014 they care most about Instagram. So
column62: and we\u2019ll post it as a Reel if we can.Scotty James\u201cWe\u2019re filming almost every day
column63: and we try to predict which Reels we post are going to blow up. Sometimes it\u2019s something cool I\u2019ve done on a snowboard
column64: or Sean\u2019s got a really great shot \u2014 we\u2019re figuring out what does really
column66: and what still does well but isn\u2019t getting 20M+ views. We\u2019re also seeing how much impact Reels have on my brand
column67: on my account following. When we get a great Reel out there
column68: it impacts my social reach and awareness an unbelievable amount. That\u2019s why we gravitate towards Reels

column8: "post_text": "CAMERON HENDERSON\u201cProducing reels is actually my main strategy at this point
column9: \u201d shared Cameron Henderson. \u201cShort-form videos are easy to create and give creators the opportunity to add more details to wow their audiences without taking up much time.\u201dAdding little details can help you capture a viewer\u2019s attention and may even have them watching more than once.Henderson\u2019s top 3 Reels tips:1Be Authentic.2Be relatable.3Captivate the audience from the very beginning.BRIANA GREEN\u201cReels are a huge factor for me. I think they\u2019re fun to create because it\u2019s shorter content
column10: straight to the point
column11: \u201d shared Briana Green. \u201cI try to come up with fun
column12: innovative and creative videos.\u201d\u201cStick to your true authentic self
column13: it\u2019s what people will gravitate to more
column14: \u201d she added.Bree\u2019s top 3 Reels tips:1Keep the videos under 20 seconds.2Craft engaging captions.3Lock in your audience in the first three seconds.JONATHAN RABBJonathan Rabb
column15: Founder and Editor-in-Chief of Watch The Yard
column16: says his team tries to post two reels every weekday \u201cto grow our audience and attract new followers.\u201dHe\u2019s also found that writing out a question at the end of the reel helps with engagement.Rabb\u2019s top 3 Reels tips:1Always include descriptive text in the reel.2Always start the reel off by showing someone's face.3Adding music always helps.EVERETT NOBLE\u201cReels help me showcase my talent to people all around the world in a short amount of time
column17: making the impact even greater
column18: \u201d shared Everett Noble.Noble\u2019s top 3 Reels tips:1Be unique
column19: forget trends. They may help you grow at first but if you're looking for longevity in your content and want people to take you seriously
column20: be different.2Quality over quantity\u2013but don\u2019t stress about being perfect. Just put out content you're proud of.3Read comments. See how the people see your work to continue to evolve. Good or bad comments always push me to thrive and change up my strategy.LALA MILAN\u201cReels help me reach bigger audiences that don\u2019t necessarily follow me. Also they make my content easier to share
column21: \u201d said LaLa Milan
column22: who added that \u201ccommenting with a question under your own post brings more interaction from followers.\u201dMilan\u2019s top 3 Reels tips:1Posting earlier in the day allows my content to reach further throughout the day.2Doing collaboration posts (\u201cCollab\u201c) brings more engagement and visibility to my page.3Remember that people\u2019s attention span attracts them to short-form video content.Read More:Bring your ideas to life with new Reels creative toolsReels Best Practices: Tips & tricks to succeed on ReelsYour go-to cheat sheet for capturing live events on Reels"}

column3: "title": "Reels Best Practices: Tips & tricks to succeed on Reels"
column7: "post_text": "1. Connettiti con il pubblicoCrea contenuti in sintonia con le persone. Se guardano il tuo reel e pensano: \"Ma sono proprio io!\"
column8: allora sei sulla strada giusta. Rappresenta situazioni in cui le persone potrebbero ritrovarsi. E guarda in camera! Prova a usare la fotocamera per i selfie per creare contenuti in prima persona e accessibili.2. Condividi il tuo punto di vista unicoLibera la tua personalit\u00e0
column9: contagia con la tua energia travolgente e mostra la tua mentalit\u00e0. Condividi le tue passioni
column10: insegna qualcosa di nuovo alle persone o mostra qualcosa che ti contraddistingue.3. Definisci la tramaI reel migliori si basano sullo storytelling. Alcuni dei pi\u00f9 popolari hanno inizio
column11: parte centrale e finale ben definiti oppure sono di grande impatto
column12: con un'importante rivelazione finale
column13: una chiusa ad effetto o un colpo di scena.4. Collegati con il presenteCondividi il tuo punto di vista sulle conversazioni del momento. Le persone vogliono sapere cosa hai da dire su qualunque cosa accada. Assicurati di interpretare tendenze e temi popolari con un tocco unico e rilevante per la tua nicchia di pubblico.Per aiutarti ad aumentare la copertura

Lancia una tendenzaCrea ispirazione lanciando una tendenza a cui le persone possano partecipare facilmente o creare un remix. Prendi ispirazione dal nostro calendario dei momenti culturali ed entra in contatto con la tua community. Ricorda: i reel non sono fatti solo per intrattenere
column15: ma anche per stimolare la partecipazione e la collaborazione creativa.6. Non avere pauraRicorda che non esiste un modo corretto per creare un reel. Fidati delle tue scelte: se un reel ti diverte
column16: \u00e8 molto probabile che avr\u00e0 lo stesso effetto anche sugli spettatori.7. Sfrutta tutti gli strumentiUsa strumenti creativi come testi
column17: filtri o effetti. Persino un elemento semplice come una transizione ben riuscita pu\u00f2 spingere le persone a guardare di nuovo il reel. Anche l'illuminazione \u00e8 importante: la luce naturale \u00e8 la scelta migliore
column18: ma evita di metterti alla luce diretta del sole o tenderai a strizzare gli occhi e ci saranno ombre. Evita anche luci dirette dall'alto e l'illuminazione alle spalle
column19: in quanto quest'ultima rischia di nascondere il tuo viso.8. Falli sognare con la libreria musicaleCrea atmosfera con musica e strumenti audio di Reels. La libreria musicale ti consente di usare il browser per trovare la musica adatta al tuo reel. Cerca per artista
column20: album o canzone oppure sfoglia musica suddivisa per genere
column21: atmosfera e tematiche. In alternativa

I video orizzontali possono risultare pesanti e non sono facile da ricreare.10. Ricerca il nuovoCi piace celebrare le sperimentazioni. Testa approcci diversi

column8: "post_text": "Stars is a virtual product that allows fans to immediately send funds to creators who are going live or posting on-demand videos. Creators who enable Stars will see these one-time payments come from dedicated fans and one-off viewers alike who are inspired and excited by their videos\u2014and fans can choose how many Stars to send based on their comfort levels and willingness to contribute. In addition to sending Stars
column9: fans can participate in fun features such as Stars Party
column10: which is a celebratory moment that automatically takes place when a creator receives a surge of Stars during a Facebook Live. During a Stars Party
column11: fans have five minutes to send a target number of Stars to try to hit a goal
column12: intended to give the creator support.In December 2021
column13: Meta hosted the first ever Stars Fest for creators
column14: featuring bonuses that allowed participants to double their Stars earnings
column15: competitions with other creators to see who could earn the most Stars that month
column16: as well as limited-time badges
column17: sales and virtual gifts. We spoke to three creators who had an exceptionally successful month with the help of Stars Fest
column18: earning additional Stars revenue (compared to their earnings from the previous month) and honing their strategy for increasing their Stars earnings long-term.Hillary Klug
column19: a professional dancing fiddler
column20: earned $973 in December 2021 from Stars during the month of Stars Fest
column21: compared to $323 the previous month. Incorporating some of her newly-honed best practices
column22: she was able to keep her earnings higher after Stars Fest

column25: earned over $2

Do so early and regularly. 2Post videos consistently and frequently.3Tell your audience what Stars means to you. 4Reward and recognize your community for using Stars. 5Create a sense of urgency

column38: in addition to mentioning Stars out loud in videos. Tell your audience what Stars means to you. Stars is one way for fans to support their favorite creators

I think that people are often grateful they have the opportunity to express themselves in this way to say thank you.\u201dShe also tells her fans that Stars represent an opportunity for them to have a conversation with her about her videos. \u201cI say
column42: for those that send Stars
column43: I respond to you personally

column45: ] but that\u2019s a way to make sure their comment is at the top of the list. I like how there\u2019s a benefit to it if someone chooses to give it

I think that people are often grateful they have the opportunity to express themselves in this way to say thank you.Dr. Jen CaudlePost videos consistently and frequently.Hillary Klug began using Stars right around the time the pandemic hit in 2020

This motivated her to post videos regularly and enabled her to continue working as a musician through the early stages of the pandemic and even grow her business. \u201cI was able to focus on my music and keep playing. I was able to produce content that was really uplifting for my audience

She sometimes reposts videos from her evergreen content library to make sure the newest members of her growing community are able to see them.December\u2019s Stars Fest motivated her to post even more. \u201cIt kept me accountable and kept me from dropping the ball on my social media

It\u2019s like the icing on the cake.Dr. Jen CaudleReward and recognize your community for using Stars.Klug pays close attention to which fans send Stars so frequently

"title": "From viral videos to Facebook Shop: Chef Simone Zanoni\u2019s recipe for community- and business-building | Meta for Creators"
column7: "post_text": "When COVID-19-related lockdowns came into effect in the spring of 2020
column8: award-winning Italian chef Simone Zanoni faced a conundrum. The Michelin-starred restaurant where he worked in Paris
column9: famed for its Mediterranean style food
column10: closed. Like many of us
column11: Zanoni found himself confined to his home with nothing to do.With a passion for food and limited outlets for creation
column12: Zanoni started to make video recipes with his wife and post them on Facebook and Instagram. His personalized style and engaging content found an audience and the pastime turned into a community\u2013and a business. ResultsMore than 25
column13: 000 orders have been placed on his Facebook and Instagram shops.Over \u20ac1.45M generated in sales.500
column14: 000 new Instagram and Facebook followers. Results provided by Simone Zanoni from May 2020 - November 2021. All results are self-reported and not identically repeatable. Generally expected individual results will differ.Si \u00e8 verificato un erroreStiamo riscontrando problemi con la riproduzione di questo video.Scopri di pi\u00f9HighlightsA tasty amuse boucheTo say that Zanoni has an engaging personal style and lively tone would be an understatement. The chef\u2019s personality-driven videos and engaging content helped attract half a million new followers to his Facebook and Instagram pages over the course of 18 months
column15: which helped him realize that there were people out there as passionate about his food as he was. Combined with his ethos of accessibility and skill sharing through tips and tricks to achieve authentic Italian cooking inexpensively
column16: Zanoni realized the impact of marrying the digital world with the real world was nothing short of revolutionary.A little help from his friendsOn top of creating and building this new community
column17: Zanoni self-published his first recipe book
column18: \u201cThe Confinement of a Chef.\u201d Helping him in this endeavor as editor was an avid fan
column19: a police officer who\u2019d cooked and tasted all of Zanoni\u2019s recipes. When the book launched on Facebook in June
column21: he sold 8K copies in 45 minutes.Shopping gets an upgradeRecipe content
column22: a growing community and a self-published book were only the beginning. Zanoni launched a shop on both Facebook and Instagram on May 31
column24: which enabled him to sell choice products alongside the videos he was organically producing.His catalog grew bit by bit: At launch
column25: he sold 2 cookbooks; now
column26: his shop offers more than 75 products including kitchenware and ingredients he uses himself. Since May 2020
column27: 25K orders have been placed
column28: generating more than \u20ac1.45M in sales. The key ingredient? Accessibility. Before the Shop was launched
column29: fans would be asking where they could buy the pasta
column30: saucepans and other ingredients they needed to cook his recipes. Tagging products in his shop meant Zanoni could respond to comments directly in a non-intrusive manner. Au naturelPart of the success of Zanoni\u2019s shop is that he manages the content himself. He has a studio at home and the creation of the videos is part of the life of the house and routine of the day. It\u2019s very much a family affair with Zanoni\u2019s wife doing the filming and his kids joining in on the fun on camera. The chef also brought on a community manager to help adapt his video strategy to a variety of formats
column31: from long-form and live to Reels
column32: as well as identify trends
column33: optimize hashtags
column34: dive into insights and more.Just dessertsIn true cyclical fashion
column35: Zanoni\u2019s success on social media\u2013which came about
column36: in large part
column37: due to the real world shutting down\u2013came full circle when restrictions eased. The Zanoni Effect filtered through to the real world with recognition in the streets
column38: and \u2014 now that restaurants are open again \u2014 a huge increase in the number of bookings made by his legion of fans. Then there\u2019s the run on guanciale that Zanoni\u2019s recipe caused
column39: having previously been a little known ingredient. In this way
column40: his lockdown experiment impacted and augmented business in real life. We have an engagement and a high volume of impressions which is fantastic
column41: I was quite impressed how this changed the economy of our restaurants.Chef Simone Zanoni"}

column8: "post_text": "We are evolving the test of our Reels Play bonus on Instagram and Facebook as we focus on investing in a suite of monetization solutions to help creators earn steady streams of income. Beginning on March 9
column10: we stopped extending new and renewed Reels Play deals for creators on Instagram and Facebook globally. We will honor existing Reels Play deals across Instagram and Facebook. To learn more about other ways to earn on Instagram and Facebook
column11: click here.Dr. Kojo Sarfo
column12: DNP
column13: is a full-time content creator with a doctorate in nursing and a background in forensic psychiatry. Sarfo discusses mental health in an accessible
column14: relatable way
column15: and shares his own journey in the process. \u201cI want you to have fun while you\u2019re healing
column16: \u201d he shared in a video he recorded in June 2021
column17: embodying the mission of his burgeoning content empire. While doing so
column18: he has grown his community across Facebook and Instagram at a meteoric rate
column19: in large part thanks to Reels and a savvy video strategy. He shared with us his tips for sustainable and meaningful growth.Results:55x times more followers on Facebook in March 2022 than March 2021190% follower growth on Instagram
column20: March 2021-March 2022907 reels created since Reels on Facebook launched
column21: September 2021-March 2022331 reels on Instagram created during the same time periodAccording to CrowdTangle & Facebook data. Results are not identically repeatable and generally expected individual results will differ. This interview has been condensed and edited for clarity.Meta: Reels on Facebook were first introduced in the US in September 2021. You were early to adopt the format and you\u2019ve seen tremendous follower growth since. What was the strategy behind that decision?Dr. Kojo Sarfo: I was already creating short-form video for other platforms
column22: including Reels on Instagram
column23: and my assistant thought there\u2019s potential [with Reels on Facebook]. I certainly think there was a \u201cfirst movers\u201d advantage but we\u2019ve been preparing for this moment. We\u2019ve experimented elsewhere.I knew that with short-form video
column24: you have to capture someone\u2019s attention within the first 2-3 seconds. So I convey my message upfront. I talk about mental health but I make it fun
column25: I rap or dance
column26: I provide a hook to draw people in. Once things start to click
column27: I look to my audience to see what resonates.How does audience insight help inform your content strategy?I saw in my audience breakdown that 85% of my followers are female
column28: so I leaned into their concerns when it comes to mental health. Things that aren\u2019t widely talked about
column29: like postpartum anxiety
column30: ADHD. I started experimenting with formats across platforms
column31: answering questions in 15-30 second videos
column32: and I noticed that the community appreciates that I get back to them in real-time.Because my audience on Facebook grew more recently
column33: I feel like I have a better handle on who they are. Possibly also because people log in using their real identities on Facebook
column34: as on Instagram
column35: I am able to click on someone\u2019s profile and learn about them from their account which helps the connection feel more authentic. These are real people
column36: and acknowledging that is crucial to community-building.Keeping things relatable
column37: connecting on an intimate level
column38: that\u2019s how I make an impact.You launched a Facebook Live series in January 2022
column39: Late Night with Dr. Kojo
column40: and you show up for your community every Monday through Thursday. How does that play into your strategy?I talk about mental health in nontraditional ways and there\u2019s an energy there. I start every episode by clapping and I make it fun. It doesn\u2019t have to be a drag
column41: it doesn\u2019t have to be dark. People tune in
column42: and they return: I have 10K-20K viewers every night and some people
column43: I know where they\u2019re from. They\u2019re like family. And that return viewership keeps me going. They get notified when I go live and it becomes like TV programming in that way. It also helps that I don\u2019t have to explain who I am or what I\u2019m about every episode
column44: these people know me. People reference past episodes in the comments.The few times I was unable to go live
column45: I let my community know. When I experimented with going live in the morning
column46: I noticed we got 2-3x the engagement. So now we\u2019re discussing what a potential live morning show format may look like.How do you stay consistent when you produce so much content? How do you avoid burnout?Having an evening show four nights a week keeps me organized. I am open about my ADHD so I need guidelines and rules to abide by
column47: and I follow a schedule.I work Monday through Thursday every week and I usually take Friday
column48: or part of Friday
column49: off. That routine is important to preventing burnout.I bookend my week with shoots: I usually shoot Sunday afternoons for a few hours
column50: and Thursday for five to six hours. In between
column51: I may record short videos on the spot. But the bulk of my series production happens on those two days.Structure and boundaries help me stay productive and I\u2019ve found that you improve your confidence when you do something with consistency.Dr. Kojo Sarfo\u2019s Top Tips for Audience Growth on Facebook:You have 2-3 seconds to capture someone\u2019s attention when it comes to short-form video
column52: like Reels. Then
column53: provide a hook to keep them watching.Look at audience insights to learn more about who\u2019s watching your content and what resonates.Try to respond to audience questions and comments in real time.If you\u2019re going live
column54: think about structuring it like a TV show. People are more likely to return and watch the next episode if they know when to expect it.Structure your week so you have shoot days
column56: and rest days.Put yourself out there and share your story authentically.You\u2019ve been able to monetize your content on Facebook. Which tools have been most effective in generating revenue?I have multiple revenue streams when it comes to Facebook:I\u2019m a part of the Reels Play Bonus program [Bonus programs enable creators to earn money based on performance
column57: earnings or content challenges. Learn more.] which has been impactful in terms of my bottom line. My payout is dependent on performance. I\u2019m also part of an engagement program that pays based on engagement on reels. In March
column58: I hit the threshold for in-stream ads and since then
column60: Late Night with Dr. Kojo. In January
column61: I turned on Subscriptions and for $4.99/month
column62: people can have early access to merch and other perks.And brand deals
column64: come through when brands see the growth and connection I have with my audience. When you focus on building an audience and providing value
column65: that\u2019s when opportunities present themselves: brand deals
column67: monetization.You are a member of We The Culture
column68: Meta\u2019s program to invest in Black creators and in the community. How has that helped fuel your success?It\u2019s been amazing. It is such a supportive program
column69: you really feel like [the people who run it] want you to win. The incentives allow me to be creative in my storytelling. That\u2019s how I came up with Life of Muo
column70: a mini-series that follows fictional recurring characters that answer mental health questions in real time.I get to learn about other creators in this space and collaborate
column71: and I get a first look at new features and products like Remix
column74: and receive support on how to use them. We get to experiment and see what the audience responds to.What\u2019s next for you?I would love to have a show where I talk to creators and people with extraordinary stories
column75: people with a positive perspective.I think we\u2019ve always talked about mental health
column76: we just got a little bit louder with it recently. Infusing my stories with current events
column78: keeps me timely. And it means I educate by entertaining. The topics may be complex but the delivery can be fun. I always think about what I want to watch
column80: and that is what I put out there.What advice do you have for creators who\u2019d like to use Meta platforms to educate and engage an audience
column81: like you have done?Put yourself out there. Take baby steps
column82: get comfortable sharing your story and what you\u2019re passionate about. You\u2019ll get better along the way.Don\u2019t care about what people think
column83: which can hold you back from being your most authentic self. But the community you build
column84: foster and nurture it. Care for it.Pace yourself. You can burn out doing things you enjoy. Figure out what you need and make sure you\u2019re getting what you need. Reinvest in yourself.\u201cThe topics may be complex but the delivery can be fun. I always think about what I want to watch
column86: and that is what I put out there.\u201dDr. Kojo Sarfo

column8: "post_text": "Updates and insights for the Reels Play bonus programAs we continue to test and refine the Reels Play bonus programs
column9: we\u2019re making some updates. We\u2019re adjusting how payouts are calculated
column10: aimed at rewarding creators across a range of audience sizes who are making high quality original content that resonates with people
column11: (which may result in payouts changing for some creators)
column12: and we\u2019re also introducing \u201cChallenges\u201d on Facebook
column13: a new incentive that helps creators in the Reels Play bonus program unlock new ways to earn from their content
column14: up to $4
column15: 000 in a given month.Here\u2019s how Challenges work:Each creator in the program will be able to participate in a series of sequential
column16: cumulative challenges each month. For example
column17: earn $20 when 5 of your Reels reach 100 plays each.When a creator completes one challenge
column18: the next challenge becomes unlocked. For example
column19: when a creator completes the 5 Reel challenge example above
column20: they would see the next one
column21: e.g.
column22: earn $100 when 20 of your Reels reach 500 plays each
column23: and so on.Creators\u2019 progress on Challenges will reset back to #1 at the start of each 30-day bonus period.We\u2019ve also heard that creators want more visibility into how their Reels are performing
column24: so we\u2019re rolling out insights for Reels Play creators on Facebook. On the Reels Play Bonus Insight page on Facebook
column25: creators can easily see how many Plays each of their eligible Reels received within the given earning period.We\u2019ll continue to test various incentive programs
column26: adjust payout pricing
column27: and apply what we learn as we expand to more creators.Check out these best practices for creating great Reels
column28: and learn more about Meta\u2019s incentive programs for creators.Expanding creator monetization options for ReelsTo help creators build sustainable businesses

column30: we\u2019ve been rolling out overlay ads in Reels on Facebook
column31: and we\u2019re starting to test them with a wider set of creators
column32: (beyond the in-stream ads program) to expand availability to more creators and open up more high quality inventory for advertisers on our platform.We\u2019ve been expanding our tests of Stars on Reels
column33: and soon
column34: Instagram creators can crosspost their Reels to Facebook
column35: giving them the ability to seamlessly share their Reels to their followers on both platforms
column36: opening up potential to grow audiences on both Instagram and Facebook. We\u2019ll also explore the ability for eligible creators to earn a share of revenue on crossposted Reels via overlay ads. Creators can also earn bonuses from both Instagram Reels Play and Facebook Reels Play."}

column7: "post_text": "Nell'ambito del nostro nuovo programma Safety School

Ognuno di questi video offrir\u00e0 importanti suggerimenti su come mantenere al sicuro la tua community. Il programma Safety School sar\u00e0 disponibile per pi\u00f9 creator quest'anno: non perderti le novit\u00e0!Video 1: Sicurezza su InstagramCorey

"title": "Daymond John celebrates black business through Facebook-exclusive Black Entrepreneurs Day event | Meta for Creators"
column8: comments
column9: and shares) on Facebook Live*6.5M+ views on Facebook Live (both live and after the event)* 36K+ peak concurrent live viewers77% of all views came from crossposting** according to event data from Meta CrowdTangle\u201cWhen I thought of Black Entrepreneurs Day
column10: I knew I couldn\u2019t do it alone. I needed great partners like Facebook to make sure that this got seen by as many people as possible. Facebook has a global community \u2014 and that\u2019s why I was excited to make this year\u2019s Black Entrepreneurs Day broadcast Facebook-exclusive.\u201dDaymond JohnOpportunity:Daymond John is an entrepreneur and TV personality
column11: best known as the founder and CEO of clothing company FUBU and co-star of ABC\u2019s four-time Emmy Award-winning reality show
column12: Shark Tank. For 12 seasons and counting
column13: Daymond and his fellow \u201csharks\u201d have listened to pitches from rising entrepreneurs before deciding whether or not to invest in their companies. Beyond the show
column14: John wanted to go further in providing opportunities for up-and-coming Black entrepreneurs. So in 2020
column15: he hosted the first Black Entrepreneurs Day \u2014 a live broadcast of conversations with Black celebrities
column16: musicians
column17: and business leaders to inspire
column18: educate
column19: and empower the next generation of Black business owners.The first event was a smashing success
column20: racking up more than seven million views across platforms and winning two Webby Awards. So for year two
column21: Daymond aimed to make the event even bigger \u2014 by hosting the second annual Black Entrepreneurs Day as a Facebook-exclusive livestream. Strategy:Daymond John chose Facebook Live as the exclusive home of his second Black Entrepreneurs Day in 2021 because of its global community. Daymond and Meta also share a common goal of providing valuable resources for Black-owned businesses and Black entrepreneurs. Part of the event\u2019s programming included a conversation with Meta VP of Business Ecosystem Partnerships Alvin Bowles and famed DJ D-Nice
column22: where they discussed the company\u2019s support of Black-owned small businesses
column23: creators
column24: and nonprofits in the U.S. The event streamed live from Harlem\u2019s legendary Apollo Theater on October 14 and featured insightful conversations with leaders in Black art
column25: culture
column26: and business. Guests included Tyra Banks
column27: Shaquille O'Neal
column28: Marcus Samuelsson
column29: Rev Run
column30: Michael Strahan
column31: Angela Yee
column32: Kevin Hart
column33: and more
column34: plus a live musical performance from Khalid. As part of the programming
column35: Daymond also gave away $250
column36: 000 to up-and-coming Black entrepreneurs via the NAACP Powershift Grant.Key Tactics:Crossposting: Daymond John employed Facebook Live Crossposting to tap into as many Facebook audiences as possible. 77% of all video views came from crossposts. Commenting: Daymond made a point of responding to fan comments during the Facebook Live as it aired. This added an extra layer of engagement for viewers
column37: who could communicate directly with him while watching the stream over its five hours. Posts where Daymond replied to fan comments received 24% more total comments than posts where he did not.Meta Horizon Venues: In addition to Facebook Live
column38: Black Entrepreneurs Day streamed live on Meta Horizon Venues
column39: allowing fans the chance to enjoy the show in virtual reality.Derivative Content Strategy: Daymond recut highlights from the Black Entrepreneurs Day event into standalone clips that people could enjoy and share. He posted 41 Facebook videos in the month following the event
column40: and those videos earned more than 2.7M views.Live Audio Rooms: Daymond was an early adopter of Live Audio Rooms
column41: a new audio format on Facebook that lets you discover
column42: listen in on
column43: and join live conversations with public figures and subject-matter experts. Since August
column44: Daymond has hosted numerous Live Audio Rooms where he has offered business advice to his community and engaged with other subject-matter experts like Amanda Cerny
column45: Billie Jean King
column46: Adam Grant
column47: Kevin O\u2019Leary
column48: Lewis Howes
column49: DJ Khaled
column50: and more. "}

column8: "post_text": "Si \u00e8 verificato un erroreStiamo riscontrando problemi con la riproduzione di questo video.Scopri di pi\u00f9Don\u2019t sleep on musicJene\u0301 Marie is a professional dancer and creator who\u2019s been posting to reels since the feature was first introduced
column9: as \u201cit spreads content to a wider audience beyond your community
column10: \u201d she told Rico. When she hops on trends and challenges
column11: she said she sees more traction and engagement.Once Remix was introduced as a creative feature
column12: Jen\u00e9 took a clever approach and remixed herself. She also teased her own reel with a pre-reel
column13: which helped her reach over 2M views.As a dancer
column14: Jen\u00e9 said
column15: reels speaks to her because music is at the heart of everything she does. She picks her track first\u2013be it a trending beat or a nostalgic tune\u2013then her outfit
column16: then builds her dance from there. Posting her reels to feed helps grow her followers
column17: she said
column18: allowing her \u201cto build a community outside of my real life community.\u201d Make content you loveComedian and creator Josh Sadowski loves making relatable content and developing characters based on his life and how he grew up. He also uses reels to write and make music. He loves the Collabs feature
column19: which means he can post content to two different accounts: his and his collaborator\u2019s. (Co-authored content means both creators share the views
column20: likes and comments from followers of both accounts.)The comedian told Rico that ideas come to him while he meditates
column21: after which he writes anything that comes to mind on paper. From there
column22: he whittles down the list to funny
column23: inspiring or emotional ideas that can play out using his characters.\u201cStaying authentic to yourself and to content you love making will keep you from burning out
column24: \u201d he advised. \u201cIf you\u2019re not feeling inspired
column25: don\u2019t force yourself. It creates pressure and can trigger anxiety. Throw content to the wall and something will stick. Have fun with it!\u201d Collaboration as a superpowerGirl group Boys World (\u201cBoys\u201d stands for Best of Your Self) uses reels to show off \u201cour music

column7: "post_text": "Three Mexican beauty and lifestyle content creators prioritized live content production with Facebook Live. In just six months
column8: they saw an exponential increase in video views and interactions on their pages.To achieve this success
column9: they identified the themes their respective audiences found most interesting and dramatically increased live video production. Creator Lupita Cardoza produced 235 live videos from May 2021 to October 2021 (352% more than the previous year) that reached more than 144 million views. \u201cBefore the last few months
column10: I didn\u2019t use live video very often. Now with the latest results
column11: they have become part of my daily content strategy
column12: \u201d Lupita said. Lupita learned the importance of pre-production
column13: from having a script with key ideas to materials and props that can be used during her broadcast. She also follows a topic schedule and is always looking for trends to generate relevant content for her audience. She\u2019s found that going live for two hours is a good length for her.  \u201cViewers like to learn about my life and my routine much more than any other subject
column14: \u201d said Lupita. \u201cAt first
column15: we tried to talk about empowerment
column16: entrepreneurship as the main nucleus. But speaking about life and showing my day to day have had more impact on my viewers.\u201d Live video also proved impactful to creators who hadn\u2019t previously experimented with the format
column17: such as Maggie Maga\u00f1a. The creator had more than 54 million views from May 2021 to October 2021 and an overall increase in her engagement on interactions
column18: comments
column19: and sharing. Now she's using live videos as part of her growing digital strategy
column20: as the video in which she shared with her fans the experience of trying an eyebrow tint. She keeps her audience preferences in mind whenever she thinks through future videos and what people are more likely to share with their friends and followers. In so far as video duration
column21: she\u2019s found that some topics are better at retaining viewers than others. A 20-minute live video
column22: she found
column23: generates strong audience engagement. Maggie has some people working for her
column24: and this teamwork has also been instrumental to her creative process. For her
column25: \"creative meetings that include brainstorming
column26: development of themes
column27: a weekly agenda and the uncovering of trends\" are fundamental to the success of live videos. Priscila Arias
column28: the creator of the La Fatshionista
column29: produced 95 videos and accumulated more than 15 million views in the period of May 2021 to October 2021
column30: an increase of 3
column31: 059% compared to the previous year. In her view
column32: content is what makes a live video successful and keeps audiences coming back\u2013not fancy sets or overpriced equipment. Priscila noted that
column33: while successful
column34: live video has its challenges
column35: namely interacting with her fans while doing another activity
column36: like putting on makeup for Halloween. Priscila has a team that helps her keep up with comments as they trickle in. In her experience
column37: engaging with fans in real time helps bolster engagement on live video. All three creators shared advice for aspiring creators who want to experiment with Facebook (or Instagram) Live: Answer fan questionsLean into tutorials
column38: teach your audience how to do somethingCollaborate with other creators; broadcast a conversation with a guestMake sure your content is personable
column39: e.g.
column40: share some activity of your daily lifeUse live to make a big announcement
column41: such as a product launch or a new business ventureHere are a few additional best practices to help you hone your live strategy: Schedule your live broadcast in advance to help maximize reach.Bet on topics relevant to your audience and make sure your stream is a minimum of 20 minutes long.Prepare a script and everything you need for the broadcast in advance.Promote your live video in other posts and stories.A Q&A session to address some fan questions.Prepare a live transmission using these tools: Live Producer and Live Broadcast.During your live broadcast
column42: mention and recognize fans who support you with Stars.Showcase the space where you create your content."}
